Soon afterward, DeJesus entered the hallway from another room.<ref name="cleveland1"/> Knight and DeJesus walked out of the home, and all three women, plus the child, were taken to [[MetroHealth|MetroHealth Medical Center]].<ref name="3 missing women found"/> Berry and DeJesus were released from the hospital the next day.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-michelle-knight-amanda-berry/2144153/ |title=2 freed women return home; 3rd still in hospital |last1=Alcindor |first1=Yamiche |last2=Bacon |first2=John |date=May 8, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509064633/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/08/cleveland-kidnap-michelle-knight-amanda-berry/2144153/ |archivedate=May 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Knight was discharged four days later, on May 10.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-captive-knight-avoids-public-family-article-1.1341364 |title=Cleveland captive Michelle Knight leaves hospital without telling family |last1=Walsh |first1=Michael |date=May 11, 2013 |newspaper=New York Daily News |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602124538/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-captive-knight-avoids-public-family-article-1.1341364 |archivedate=June 2, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Arrest and legal proceedings== [[File:Ariel Castro FBI interrogation.png|thumbnail|right|Screenshot showing Castro's interrogation by the FBI]] Castro was arrested on May 6, 2013.<ref name="plain-dealer-charges"/> He was charged with four counts of kidnapping and three counts of rape on May 8, which carry [[prison sentence]]s of ten years to life in Ohio.<ref name="plain-dealer-charges"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2971.03 |title=2971.03 Sentencing for sexually violent predator specification |publisher=LAWriter – ORC |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513054559/http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2971.03 |archivedate=May 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Two of Castro's brothers were also initially taken into custody, but were released on May 9 after police announced that they had no involvement in the kidnappings.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-suspects-brothers-released-custody |title=Ohio suspect's brothers released from custody |date=May 9, 2013 |publisher=Yahoo! |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609021837/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-suspects-brothers-released-custody |archivedate=June 9, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Castro made his first court appearance at the Cleveland [[Ohio Municipal Courts|Municipal Court]] on May 9, where [[bail]] was set at $2 million per kidnapping charge, adding to a total of $8 million.<ref name="LA Times bail">{{cite news|last=Muskal|first=Michael|title=Ariel Castro's bail set at $8 million in Cleveland abduction case|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-bail-set-cleveland-20130509,0,6364727.story|accessdate=May 15, 2013|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 9, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516120848/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-bail-set-cleveland-20130509,0,6364727.story|archivedate=May 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Washington Post man accused">{{cite news|last=Markon|first=Jerry|title=Cleveland man accused of kidnapping, raping 3 women held on $8 million bond|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/man-accused-of-kidnapping-raping-3-women-held-on-8-million-bond/2013/05/09/3a7656b0-b8e7-11e2-92f3-f291801936b8_story.html|accessdate=May 15, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 9, 2013|last2=Wilgoren|first2=Debbi|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512141934/http://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/man-accused-of-kidnapping-raping-3-women-held-on-8-million-bond/2013/05/09/3a7656b0-b8e7-11e2-92f3-f291801936b8_story.html|archivedate=May 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/cleveland-ariel-castro-amanda-berry-arraignment-kidnap-rape/2146289/ |title=Prosecutor: Ariel Castro could face death penalty |last1=Leger |first1=Donna Leinwand |last2=Strauss |first2=Gary |date=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511091619/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/09/cleveland-ariel-castro-amanda-berry-arraignment-kidnap-rape/2146289/ |archivedate=May 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Additional charges were reported to be pending, including [[Aggravation (law)|aggravated murder]] (for intentional induction of miscarriages), [[attempted murder]], [[assault]], a charge for each alleged instance of rape, and a kidnapping charge for each day each captive was allegedly held.<ref name="pd090513"/> On May 14, Castro's attorneys said he would plead "not guilty" to all charges if indicted for kidnapping and rape.<ref name="WKYC Investigator">{{cite news|last=Meyer |first=Tom |title=Investigator: Castro loves daughter, will plead 'not guilty' |url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/299605/45/Investigator-Castro-loves-daughter-will-plead-not-guilty |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615114847/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/299605/45/Investigator-Castro-loves-daughter-will-plead-not-guilty |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 15, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |date=May 14, 2013 }}</ref><ref name="BBC to plead innocent">{{cite news|title=Cleveland kidnap accused Castro to plead innocent – lawyers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22543247|accessdate=May 15, 2012|publisher=BBC|date=May 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516014858/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-22543247|archivedate=May 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Reuters to plead not guilty">{{cite news|author=Palmer, Kim|title=Accused Cleveland kidnapper plans to plead not guilty: lawyer|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/15/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE94E0LT20130515|accessdate=May 15, 2013|agency=Reuters|date=May 15, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515220240/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/15/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE94E0LT20130515|archivedate=May 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] [[grand jury]] returned a [[Indictment|true bill]] of indictment against Castro on June 7. It contained 329 counts, including two counts of aggravated murder (under different sections of the Ohio criminal code) for his alleged role in the termination of one of the women's pregnancies. The indictments covered only the period from August 2002 to February 2007. The county prosecutor, Timothy J. McGinty, stated that the investigation was ongoing, and that any further findings would be presented to the grand jury. McGinty said that pursuing a [[death penalty]] specification would be considered following completion of indictment proceedings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/06/ariel_castro_indicted_on_charg.html |title=Ariel Castro indicted on aggravated murder, rape, kidnapping charges |last=McCarty |first=James F. |date=June 7, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907111035/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/06/ariel_castro_indicted_on_charg.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ohio grand jury indicts man accused of kidnapping Cleveland women |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/08/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE95619F20130608?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews&dlvrit=992637 |last1=Palmer |first=Kim |date=June 8, 2013 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608025533/http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/08/us-usa-missing-ohio-idUSBRE95619F20130608?feedType=RSS |archivedate=June 8, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
After entering a not guilty plea for Castro on June 12, one of his attorneys, Craig Weintraub, said that although some of the charges against Castro were indisputable, "it is our hope that we can continue to work toward a resolution to avoid having an unnecessary trial about aggravated murder and the death penalty". He noted, "We are very sensitive to the emotional strain and impact that a trial would have on the women, their families and this community".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-plea-20130612,0,6763994.story |title=Ariel Castro's lawyer: Some kidnap charges 'cannot be disputed' |last=Pearce |first=Matt |date=June 12, 2013 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=June 19, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615022557/http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-ariel-castro-plea-20130612,0,6763994.story |archivedate=June 15, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro was found competent to stand trial on July 3.<ref>{{cite news |title=Accused Cleveland kidnapper ruled capable of standing trial |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/03/justice/ohio-castro-hearing/index.html |date=July 3, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907063712/http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/03/justice/ohio-castro-hearing/index.html |archivedate=September 7, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On July 12, a Cuyahoga County grand jury returned a true bill of indictment for the remainder of the period after February 2007. It brought the total to 977 counts: 512 counts of kidnapping, 446 of rape, seven of gross sexual imposition, six of felonious assault, three of [[child endangerment]], two of aggravated murder, and one of possession of criminal tools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/12/justice/ohio-castro-indictment/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |title=Cleveland kidnapping suspect now faces 977 counts |date=July 13, 2013 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=July 13, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130713162930/http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/12/justice/ohio-castro-indictment/index.html?hpt=hp_t2 |archivedate=July 13, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> On July 17, Castro pleaded not guilty to the expanded indictment.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheeran|first=Thomas J.|title=Ohio kidnapping, rape suspect pleads not guilty|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2nd-arraignment-set-ohio-kidnap-suspect|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=October 4, 2013|date=July 17, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131004225023/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/2nd-arraignment-set-ohio-kidnap-suspect|archivedate=October 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Castro pleaded guilty on July 26 to 937 of the 977 charges against him, including charges of kidnapping, rape, and aggravated murder, as part of a [[plea bargain]] which called for consecutive sentences of [[life imprisonment|life in prison]] plus 1,000 years, all without [[parole]].<ref name=usat072613/> Under the plea deal, Castro forfeited his right to [[appeal]], and could not profit in any way due to his crimes. He also forfeited his assets, including his home, which prosecutors said would be demolished.<ref name=cl072613>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_agrees_to_plea_de.html |title=Ariel Castro agrees to plea deal: Life in prison, no parole, plus 1,000 years for abduction, rapes of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight |last1=Krouse |first1=Peter |date=July 26, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=July 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730041818/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/ariel_castro_agrees_to_plea_de.html |archivedate=July 30, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro was told by Cuyahoga County [[Ohio Courts of Common Pleas|Common Pleas Court]] Judge Michael Russo, "You will not be getting out. Is that clear?" to which Castro responded, "I do understand that, your honor."<ref name="BBC-plea">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-23468222 |title=Ariel Castro to serve life in prison under plea deal |publisher=BBC News |date=July 26, 2013 |accessdate=July 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727013327/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-23468222 |archivedate=July 27, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Castro also made comments about his "addiction to [[pornography]]" and "sexual problem", but was cut off by Judge Russo, who said such issues could be discussed at the August 1 sentencing hearing.<ref name=cl072613/> A law firm representing Berry, DeJesus, and Knight released a statement that the three women were "relieved by today's plea. They are satisfied by this resolution to the case, and are looking forward to having these legal proceedings draw to a final close in the near future".<ref name=cl072613/>
At the sentencing hearing on August 1, Castro was sentenced to consecutive life terms in prison, plus 1,000 years, all without any possibility of parole. He was also fined $100,000. The court forfeited all of his property and assets to the Cuyahoga County government.<ref name=pd130801>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/08/judge_sends_ariel_castro_to_pr.html |title=Judge sends Ariel Castro to prison for abduction, rape of Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight (slideshow) |date=August 1, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=August 6, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804045059/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/08/judge_sends_ariel_castro_to_pr.html |archivedate=August 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Before his sentencing, Castro addressed the court for twenty minutes, in which he said he was "a good person" and "not a monster", but that he was addicted to sex and pornography, and had "practiced the art of [[masturbation]]" from a young age. He claimed that he had never beaten or tortured the women, and insisted that "most" of the sex he had with them "was consensual". He shifted between an apologetic tone and blaming the FBI for failing to catch him, as well as his victims themselves, insisting to the court that when he had sex with them he discovered they were not virgins. He would alternatively shift back into apologetic comments, saying: "I hope they can find in their hearts to forgive me because we had a lot of harmony going on in that home".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130806234708/http://www.wkyc.com/news/article/308810/45/STATEMENT--Read-Ariel-Castros-final-remarks-in-court |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 6, 2013 |title=Ariel Castro spoke for 20 minutes in court, read what he said here |date=August 1, 2013 |publisher=WKYC |accessdate=August 6, 2013 }}</ref>
The sentencing judge also heard from Knight and family members of Berry and DeJesus. Knight told Castro: "You took eleven years of my life away. I spent eleven years in hell, now your hell is just beginning. I will overcome all that has happened, but you will face hell for eternity. I will live on, you will die a little every day as you think of the eleven years of atrocities that you inflicted on us... I can forgive you, but I will never forget."<ref name=pd130801/>
==Aftermath== ===Survivors=== On July 9, 2013, Knight, Berry, and DeJesus broke their public silence for the first time since their rescue by releasing a video statement thanking the public for their support. An attorney for Berry and DeJesus said the women "still have a strong desire for privacy" and did not wish to speak to the media about their ordeal.<ref name=pd070913>{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |title=New video: Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus and Michelle Knight, Cleveland's 3 missing women, thank you for your support |last1=Caniglia |first1=John |date=July 9, 2013 |newspaper=The Plain Dealer |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710092111/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/07/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_and_2.html |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |title=TRANSCRIPT: Cleveland kidnapping victims say thank you for support |last1=Steer |first1=Jen |date=July 9, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711210648/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/transcript-cleveland-kidnapping-victims-say-thank-for-support |archivedate=July 11, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Cleveland Courage Fund, a bank account set up to help the women in their transition to independent life, had collected approximately $1.05 million at the time of the video's release.<ref name=pd070913/> Before Berry's disappearance, her grandfather had promised to give her a classic [[Chevrolet Monte Carlo]] from the year Berry was born. He kept the car after her kidnapping, in case she was still found alive. After her rescue, Berry called her grandfather, and asked if he still had the car, which he did,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |title=Amanda Berry's grandfather keeps 1986 Monte Carlo he promised before she went missing |last1=Kiesel |first1=Connor |publisher=Newsnet5.com |date=May 13, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130710181505/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/cleveland_metro/amanda-berrys-grandfather-keeps-1986-monte-carlo-he-promised-before-she-went-missing |archivedate=July 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> although it was in need of [[automotive restoration|restoration]] from having gone unused. Several automotive shops offered to perform the restoration for free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite |title=Amanda Berry and grandfather reunite |last1=Morabito |first1=Nate |publisher=WJHL |date=April 17, 2013 |accessdate=July 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801005123/http://www.wjhl.com/story/22285475/amanda-berry-and-grandfather-reunite|archivedate=August 1, 2013}}</ref>
In an interview with [[People (magazine)|''People'' magazine]] on the first anniversary of her rescue, Knight discussed some of her ordeals as well as her life leading up to her abduction. Since her rescue, she legally changed her first name to Lily,<ref>{{cite news|last=Feran|first=Tom|title=Michelle Knight conquers her fears after 'dangling in the wind'|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|accessdate=March 16, 2015|newspaper=The Plain Dealer|date=March 14, 2015|quote=Knight has changed her own name legally to Lily[...]but she uses her better-known birth name in public appearances.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316233918/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/03/michelle_knight_1.html|archivedate=March 16, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and began to get several tattoos as her way of coping with the healing process. Knight also revealed that her son was adopted by his [[foster care|foster parents]] while she was in captivity, and that while she wanted to see him, she does not want to bring him into the ordeal she has had to deal with, and planned to see him after he becomes an adult. Knight planned to open a restaurant, dreamed of getting married — which she did in 2016<ref>{{cite news|title=Michelle Knight, kept in captivity for over 10 years, reveals her marriage on "Dr. Phil"|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|work=[[CBS News]]|date=April 10, 2018|access-date=April 11, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180411102025/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/michelle-knight-kept-in-captivity-for-over-10-years-reveals-her-marriage-on-dr-phil/|archivedate=April 11, 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> — and adopt children. Knight also planned to reunite with Berry and DeJesus in the future, but began focusing on getting her own life back on track.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|title=Cleveland Kidnapping Victim Michelle Knight Tells Her Story of Torture and Triumph|publisher=People.com|date=May 9, 2014|accessdate=November 9, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108191416/http://www.people.com/article/michelle-knight-cleveland-kidnapping-book-excerpt|archivedate=November 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Berry and DeJesus received honorary diplomas from John Marshall High School in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|title=Amanda Berry, Gina DeJesus realize high school graduation dream with John Marshall Class of 2015|newspaper=cleveland.com|access-date=January 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018015223/http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2015/05/amanda_berry_gina_dejesus_real.html|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===House demolition=== [[File:Seymour Avenue - panoramio.jpg|thumbnail|right|The site on Seymour Avenue in 2014.]] As part of the plea bargain, the house where Castro lived, and where he had held the women captive, was demolished on August 7, 2013. Knight was present and handed out yellow balloons, which she said represented missing children, to the gathered crowd. The balloons were released before DeJesus's aunt began the demolition with a swing of a [[crane (machine)|crane]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |title=Cleveland house of horrors destroyed — demolition crews tear down Ariel Castro's home |last1=Kemp |first1=Joe |date=August 7, 2013 |newspaper=NY Daily News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810195725/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/cleveland-house-horrors-destroyed-demolition-crews-tear-ariel-castro-home-article-1.1419792 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |title=Cleveland Kidnapper Ariel Castro's 'House of Horrors' Demolished |last1=Ng |first1=Christina |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810182609/http://abcnews.go.com/US/cleveland-kidnapper-ariel-castros-house-horrors-demolished/story?id=19890927 |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |title=Michelle Knight held captive for decade by Ariel Castro hands out yellow balloons on Seymour Avenue |last1=Seitz |first1=Colleen |date=August 7, 2013 |publisher=newsnet5.com |accessdate=August 7, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130810222225/http://www.newsnet5.com/dpp/news/local_news/oh_cuyahoga/michelle-knight-held-captive-for-decade-by-ariel-castro-hands-out-yellow-balloons-on-seymour-avenue |archivedate=August 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Castro's death === On the evening of September 3, 2013, one month into his life sentence, Castro was found hanging with a bed sheet in his detention cell at the [[Correctional Reception Center]] in [[Orient, Ohio]].<ref name="AP suicide">{{cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-man-who-held-3-women-captive-found-dead |title=Cleveland man's suicide brings little sympathy |last1=Sheeran |first1=Thomas J. |last2=Welsh-Huggins |first2=Andrew |date=September 4, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20131004072333/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ohio-man-who-held-3-women-captive-found-dead |archivedate=October 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Prison staff performed [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on Castro before he was taken to the [[Wexner Medical Center at Ohio State University|Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center]] in [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], where he was pronounced dead shortly thereafter.<ref name="AP suicide"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Woods|first=Jim|title=Ariel Castro dies in apparent suicide|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-commits-suicide-in-prison.html|newspaper=The Columbus Dispatch|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=September 4, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906090516/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/public/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-commits-suicide-in-prison.html|archivedate=September 6, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated9">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/justice/ariel-castro-cleveland-kidnapper-death/?hpt=hp_t1 |last1=Mungin |first1=Lateef |last2=Alsup |first2=Dave |publisher=CNN |date=September 4, 2013 |title=Ariel Castro, Cleveland kidnapper, found hanged in prison cell |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JNhFIjnY?url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/09/04/justice/ariel-castro-cleveland-kidnapper-death/?hpt=hp_t1 |archivedate=September 4, 2013 |accessdate=September 4, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> The following day, [[Franklin County, Ohio|Franklin County]] [[coroner]] Dr. Jan Gorniak announced that a preliminary [[autopsy]] had found the cause of Castro's death to be suicide by hanging.<ref name="usatoday-Eversley">{{cite news|last=Eversley|first=Melanie|title=The Ohio kidnapper was not on suicide watch, but was checked on every 30 minutes by guards.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-hung-prison/2761177/|accessdate=September 4, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=September 4, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904195004/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/09/04/ariel-castro-hung-prison/2761177/|archivedate=September 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On October 10, 2013, the [[Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction]] released a report that suggested Castro may have died accidentally from auto-[[erotic asphyxiation]] rather than suicide. Gorniak rejected the possibility, standing by her ruling of suicide. The report also said two prison guards had falsified logs documenting their observation of Castro hours before he was found dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Castro suicide report: Officers falsified reports|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|publisher=The Columbus Dispatch|accessdate=October 10, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010150554/http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2013/10/10/Ariel-Castro-suicide-report.html|archivedate=October 10, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Castro was not on [[suicide watch]] at the time of his death, but had been subject to routine checks every thirty minutes due to his notoriety.<ref name="AP suicide"/>
A consultant's report was released on December 3, and officially concluded that "all available evidence pointed to suicide, including a shrine-like arrangement of family pictures and a Bible in Castro's cell, an increasing tone of frustration in his prison journal and the reality of spending the rest of his life in prison while subject to constant harassment." The [[Ohio State Highway Patrol]] also reviewed the case and reached the same conclusion.<ref name="suiciderpt">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |title=Consultants: Kidnapper Ariel Castro's death a suicide |last=Welsh-Huggins |first1=Andrew |date=December 3, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206061146/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/12/03/consultants-ariel-castro-death-suicide/3850515/ |archivedate=December 6, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Castro, Ariel}} [[Category:2000s missing person cases]] [[Category:2002 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:2002 in Ohio]] [[Category:2003 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:2003 in Ohio]] [[Category:2004 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:2004 in Ohio]] [[Category:2013 in Ohio]] [[Category:21st century in Cleveland]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:August 2002 events]] [[Category:Crimes in Cleveland]] [[Category:Formerly missing people]] [[Category:Kidnapped American children]] [[Category:Kidnappings in the United States]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Ohio]] [[Category:Torture in the United States]] [[Category:People from Cleveland]] [[Category:Rape in the United States]] [[Category:Violence against women in the United States]]

The '''Belyayev circle''' ({{lang-ru|'''Беляевский кружок'''}}) was a society of Russian musicians who met in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]] between 1885 and 1908, and whose members included [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]], [[Alexander Glazunov]], [[Vladimir Stasov]], [[Anatoly Lyadov]], [[Alexander Ossovsky]], [[Witold Maliszewski]], [[Nikolai Tcherepnin]], [[Nikolay Sokolov (composer)|Nikolay Sokolov]], [[Alexander Winkler (composer)|Alexander Winkler]] among others. The circle was named after [[Mitrofan Belyayev]], a [[lumber|timber]] merchant and amateur musician who became a music philanthropist and publisher after hearing the music of the teenage Glazunov.
The Belyayev circle believed in a [[musical nationalism|national]] style of classical music, based on the achievements of the composer group [[The Five (composers)|The Five]] which preceded it. One important difference between composers in the Belyayev circle and their counterparts in the Five was an acceptance in the necessity of Western-styled academic training; this was an attitude passed down by Rimsky-Korsakov, who taught many of the composers in the circle at the [[Saint Petersburg Conservatory]]. While these composers were more open to Western compositional practices and influences, especially through the music of [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]], they closely followed many of the compositional practices of the Five to the point of mannerism, especially in their depiction of folkloric subject matter.
The Belyayev circle came to dominate musical life in St. Petersburg. Composers who desired patronage, publication or public performance of their works through Belyayev were compelled to write in a musical style accepted by Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov. There was also peer pressure to compose in this style, as well as a distrust of composers who did not do so. Several composers who believed in the philosophy of the Belyayev circle became professors and heads of music conservatories in Russia, which extended the influence of the group past the physical confines of St. Petersburg and timewise well into the 20th century.
==Belyayev== {{see also|Mitrofan Belyayev}} [[File:Belyayev by Repin.jpg|thumb|180px|right|alt=A middle-aged man with medium-length dark hair and a beard, wearing a dark suit, with one hand in his trouser pocket and the other hand on his chin|Portrait of [[Mitrofan Belyayev]] by [[Ilya Repin]]]]
Belyayev was one of a growing number of Russian nouveau-riche industrialists who became patrons of the arts in mid- to late-19th century Russia; their number included Nadezhda von Meck, railway magnate [[Savva Mamontov]] and textile manufacturer [[Pavel Tretyakov]].<ref>Figes, 195–197; Maes, 173–174, 196–197.</ref> While Nadezhda von Meck insisted on anonymity in her patronage in the tradition of ''[[noblesse oblige]]'', Belyayev, Mamontov and Tretyakov "wanted to contribute conspicuously to public life".<ref name="taruskin49">Taruskin, 49.</ref> Because of their cultural and political orientation, they were more likely than the aristocracy to support native talent, and were more inclined to support nationalist artists over cosmopolitan ones.<ref name="taruskin42"/> This was not due to any social or political agenda implicit in the art, but due to the Russianness of the art itself.<ref name="taruskin42">Taruskin, 42.</ref> This included the music of the composers Belyayev chose to support.<ref name="taruskin42"/>
An amateur [[viola]] player and [[chamber music]] enthusiast, Belyayev hosted "[[string quartet|quartet]] Fridays" at his home in St. Petersburg. A frequent visitor to these gatherings was Rimsky-Korsakov.<ref>Maes, 172–173.</ref> Belyayev became a music patron after he had heard the [[Symphony No. 1 (Glazunov)|First Symphony]] by the sixteen-year-old Glazunov, who had been discovered by Balakirev and tutored by Rimsky-Korsakov in musical composition, [[counterpoint]] and orchestration. Not only did Glazunov become a fixture of the "quartet Fridays", but Belyayev also published Glazunov's work and took him on a tour of Western Europe. This tour included a visit to [[Weimar]], [[Germany]] to present the young composer to famed Hungarian composer and pianist [[Franz Liszt]].<ref name="maes192">Maes, 192.</ref>
Soon Belyayev became interested in other Russian composers. In 1884 he set up an annual [[Glinka prize]], named after pioneer Russian composer [[Mikhail Glinka]] (1804–1857). In 1885 he founded his own music publishing firm, based in [[Leipzig]], Germany, through which he published works by Glazunov, Rimsky-Korsakov, Lyadov and Borodin at his own expense.<ref name="maes173"/> By publishing in Leipzig, Belyayev could offer the double benefit of higher quality music printing than was available in Russia at the time, plus the protection of international [[copyright]] which Russia did not offer.<ref name="taruskin49"/> At Rimsky-Korsakov's suggestion, Belyayev also founded his own concert series, the [[Russian Symphony Concerts]], open exclusively to Russian composers. Among the works written especially for this series were the three by Rimsky-Korsakov by which he is currently best known in the West—''[[Scheherazade]]'', the ''[[Russian Easter Festival Overture]]'' and ''[[Capriccio espagnol]]''. To select which composers to assist with money, publication or performances from the many who now appealed for help, Belyayev set up an advisory council made up of Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov. They would look through the compositions and appeals submitted and suggest which composers were deserving of patronage and public attention.<ref name="maes173">Maes, 173.</ref>
==Influence== The musical scene in St. Petersburg came to be dominated by the Belyayev circle since Rimsky-Korsakov had taught many of its members at the Conservatory there. Since Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov acted in an advisory capacity to the Belyayev enterprises, and thus became channels of Belyayev's largesse,<ref name="taruskin56"/> composers who wished to be part of this circle and who desired Belyayev's patronage had to write in a musical style approved by these three men.<ref name="maes173"/> Because of this stricture, Rimsky-Korsakov's style became the preferred academic style—one that young composers had to follow if they hoped to have any sort of career.<ref name="maes173">Maes, 173.</ref> In this sense, the Belyayev circle acted as a compositional [[guild]].<ref name="taruskin56"/> The better pupils from the St. Petersburg Conservatory received initiation by their invitation to the "quartet Fridays", and admission to the circle "guaranteed well remunerated publication by Edition Belieff, Leipzig, and performance in the Russian Symphony Concert programs".<ref name="taruskin56">Taruskin, 56.</ref> Thus, the Belyayev circle "set up an establishment that governed all aspects of musical creation, education and performance".<ref name="taruskin56"/>
==Philosophy== The Belyayev circle ran counter in its philosophy to the artistic movement and magazine ''[[Mir iskusstva]]'' ({{lang-ru|«Мир иску́сства»}}, ''World of Art''). ''Mir iskusstva'' "identified with the artistic values of the [Russian] aristocracy" in its cosmopolitanism and belief of a universal culture.<ref>Figes, 268–269.</ref> The composers of the Belyayev circle, like the Five before it, believed in a national, realist form of Russian classical music that should stand apart in its style and characteristics from Western European classical music. In this sense, the Belyayev composers shared similar goals with the [[Abramtsevo Colony]] and [[Russian Revival architecture|Russian Revival]] in the sphere of fine arts. Another way ''Mir iskusstva'' disagreed with the Belyayev circle was that they believed the composers under Belyayev were practicing art for art's sake, much like a social program. This practice ran counter to their belief in focusing on "art as the spiritual expression of the individual's creative genius", as they felt [[Alexander Pushkin]] had done in his poetry and Tchaikovsky in his music.<ref>Figes, 269.</ref> Alfred Nurok commented in an 1899 review in ''Mir iskusstva'':
{{quote|Mr. Belyayev's [[Gaius Maecenas|Maecenas]] activities bear a very special imprint. His undeniably lavish patronage of Russian music of the newest variety does not, unfortunately, so much facilitate the development of the talents of gifted but as yet unrecognized composers, as it encourages young people who have successfully completed their conservatory course to cultivate productivity come what may, touching little upon the question of their creative abilities. Mr. Belyayev encourages industry above all, and under his [[aegis]] musical composition has assumed the character of a workers' collective (''[[artel]]''), or even a crafts industry.|<ref>As cited in Maes, 173.</ref>}}
Musicologist [[Richard Taruskin]] writes, "Within the Belyayev circle a safe conformism became increasingly the rule".<ref name="taruskin57">Taruskin, 57.</ref> Concert programs needed to be filled with new Russian works, and new works had to be published to offer to the music public. It was therefore necessary "to dip rather deep into the pool of available Conservatory trained talent", and the circle became known for the number of less-than-first-rate talents harbored within it.<ref name="taruskin57"/> Critic and composer [[César Cui]], who had been part of the Five along with Rimsky-Korsakov, derisively called these younger composers "clones".<ref name="taruskin57"/> Though there was some snobbism involved in criticism of the Belyayev circle, there was also enough truth in the issue of conformism to cause the circle some embarrassment.<ref name="taruskin57"/> A contributing factor to this conformism was the gradual academization of composers in the nationalist circle, fueled by Rimsky-Korsakov's efforts in this regard with his students.<ref name="mfw21403">Frolova-Walker, ''New Grove (2001)'', 21:403.</ref> An increasing number of these students joined the Belyayev circle; the result was "the emergence of production-line 'Russian style' pieces, polished and correct, but lacking originality".<ref name="mfw21403"/>
==Comparison to the Five== [[File:Glazunov by Repin.jpg|thumb|alt=A young man with reddish hair wearing a dark suit|Portrait of [[Alexander Glazunov]] by [[Ilya Repin]], 1887]]
The composers who formed the Belyayev circle were nationalistic in their outlook, as were the Five before them. Like the Five, they believed in a uniquely Russian style of classical music that utilized folk music and exotic melodic, harmonic and rhythmic elements, as exemplified by the music of Balakirev, Borodin and Rimsky-Korsakov. Unlike the Five, these composers also believed in the necessity of an academic, Western-based background in composition. The necessity of Western compositional techniques was something that Rimsky-Korsakov had instilled in many of them in his years at the St. Petersburg Conservatory.<ref name="maes192"/> Compared to the "revolutionary" composers in Balakirev's circle, Rimsky-Korsakov found those in the Belyayev circle to be "progressive ... attaching as it did great importance to technical perfection, but ... also broke new paths, though more securely, even if less speedily...."<ref name="rk286">Rimsky-Korsakov, 286–287.</ref>
Glazunov's attitude toward outside influences was typical of the Belyayev circle. He studied Tchaikovsky's works and "found much that was new ... that was instructive for us as young musicians. It struck me that Tchaikovsky, who was above all a lyrical and melodic composer, had introduced operatic elements into his symphonies. I admired the thematic material of his works less than the inspired unfolding of his thoughts, his temperament and the constructural perfection."<ref>Quoted in Lobanova, 6.</ref> Rimsky-Korsakov noted "a tendency toward [[eclecticism]]" among the composers in the Belyayev circle, as well as a "predilection ... for Italian-French music of the time of wig and [[farthingale]] [that is, the eighteenth century], music introduced by Tchaikovsky in his ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|Queen of Spades]]'' and ''[[Iolanthe (Tchaikovsky)|Iolanthe]]''".<ref>Rimsky-Korsakov, 309.</ref>
Nevertheless, while the Belyayev circle was more tolerant of outside influence to a certain degree than their predecessors under Balakirev,<ref>Schwarz, ''New Grove (1980)'', 7:428.</ref> they still followed the compositional practices of the Five closely. Maes writes, "The harmonies of [[Modest Mussorgsky|Mussorgsky]]'s coronation scene in ''[[Boris Godunov (opera)|Boris]]'', the [[octatonic scale|octatonicism]] of ''[[Mlada (Rimsky-Korsakov)|Mlada]]'' and ''[[Sadko (opera)|Sadko]]'', Balakirev's folk-song stylizations, Rimsky-Korsakov's colorful [[harmony|harmonization]]—all these served as a store of recipes for writing Russian national music. In the portrayal of the national character ... these techniques prevailed over the subjects portrayed".<ref name="maes192"/>
==Folklorism, orientalism, "fantastic" style== Unlike their predecessors in the Five, composers in the Belyayev circle did not concern themselves greatly with [[fakelore|folklorism]]—the invention or adaptation of [[folklore]] to newly written stories or songs, or to folklore that is reworked and modified for modern tastes. They also did not travel to other parts of Russia to actively search for folk songs, as Balakirev had done. When the Belyayev composers produced folkloric works, "they simply imitated Balakirev's or Rimsky-Korsakov's styles".<ref>Maes, 192–193.</ref>
One of the Belyayev composers, [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]], continued the Five's work in musical [[orientalism]]—the use of exotic melodic, harmonic and rhythmic elements to depict the middle- and far-eastern parts of the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>Figes, 390–391; Maes, 80–83.</ref> He wrote three operas set in an oriental background and composed in Balakirev's style—''Ruth'', ''Azra'' and ''Izmena''. The story for the last of these operas "deals with the struggle between Christians and Muslims during the sixteenth-century occupation of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] by the Persians".<ref name="maes193">Maes, 193.</ref> Ippolotov-Ivanov is best known in the West for his two sets of ''[[Caucasian Sketches]]'' "an orientalist orchestral work modeled on Balakirev and Borodin".<ref name="maes193"/>
Lyadov wrote in a "fantastic" vein akin to Rimsky-Korsakov's, especially in his tone poems based on Russian fairy tales, ''Baba Yaga'', ''Kikimora'' and ''The Enchanted Lake''.<ref name="maes192">Maes, 192.</ref> This style of musical writing was based on extensive use of the [[whole tone scale]] and the [[octatonic scale]] to depict supernatural or magical characters and events, hence the term "fantastic".<ref>Maes, 83–84.</ref> Though he would break from the Belyayev aesthetic in subsequent works, [[Igor Stravinsky]] wrote his [[Ballet (music)|ballet]] ''[[The Firebird]]'' in a similar musical style.<ref>Maes, 219.</ref>
==Intolerance of non-compliant composers== [[File:Young Rachmaninoff 2.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A clean-shaven young man with close-cropped hair, wearing a dark jacket, dress shirt with a high stiff collar and tie, looking toward the viewer with one hand on the side of his head|Sergei Rachmaninoff]]
Despite Rimsky-Korsakov's denial of bias among composers of the Belyayev circle,<ref name="rk286"/> musicologist [[Solomon Volkov]] mentions that they and the Five shared a mutual suspicion of compositions that did not follow its canon.<ref name="volkov350">Volkov, ''St. Petersburg'', 350.</ref> This proved especially true of the [[Symphony No. 1 (Rachmaninoff)|First Symphony]] of [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]], a Moscow composer and protege of Tchaikovsky. Rimsky-Korsakov, whose own musical preferences in his later years were not overly progressive,<ref>Maes, 180—181.</ref> may have sounded an advance warning on hearing the symphony in rehearsal when he told Rachmaninoff, "Forgive me, but I do not find this music at all agreeable".<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 71.</ref> By the reports of many present, the rehearsal that Rimsky-Korsakov had heard, conducted by Glazunov, was both a disaster as a performance and a horrific travesty of the score.<ref name="har76">Harrison, 76.</ref> The premiere, held in St. Petersburg on March 28, 1897, went no better. Cui wrote in his review of the work, among other things, "If there were a [[College or university school of music|conservatory]] in [[Hell]], and if one of its talented students were to compose a programme symphony based on the story of the [[Plagues of Egypt|Ten Plagues of Egypt]], and if he were to compose a symphony like Mr. Rachmaninoff's, then he would have fulfilled his task brilliantly and would delight the inhabitants of Hell".<ref>Cui, Ts., "Tretiy russkiy simfonicheskiy kontsert," ''Novosti i birzhevaya gazeta'' (17 March 1897(o.s.), 3.</ref> The symphony was not performed again in Rachmaninoff's lifetime,<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 74.</ref> and while Rachmaninoff did not destroy or disavow the score, he suffered a psychological collapse that led to a three-year creative hiatus.<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 144–145; Norris, ''Rachmaninoff'', 97.</ref>
==Modernism== Maes writes that the composers who formed the Belyayev circle have often been described as "important links to, and pathbreakers for" modernist Russian composers such as Stravinsky and [[Sergei Prokofiev]]. This, he asserts, is actually a false assumption which suggests that modernism was the result of a gradual process.<ref name="maes195">Maes, 195.</ref> The truth, Maes suggests, was that modernist music in Russia was a much more radical break from the Belyayev circle than many have claimed.<ref name="maes195"/> Rimsky-Korsakov's extensive use of the [[octatonic scale]] and other harmonic experiments "was a gold mine for those bent on a modernist revolution," Maes writes. "However, the renewing force had still to be liberated from the cliches and routines into which the Belyayev aesthetic had been pressed".<ref name="maes195"/>
==Legacy== [[File:Dmitrij Dmitrijevič Šostakovič (Дми́трий Дми́триевич Шостако́вич).jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A young man wearing round-framed glasses, a dark jacket, tie and dress shirt|Dmitri Shostakovich, 1925]]
Bias toward the musical aesthetics practiced by the Belyayev circle would continue at the St. Petersburg Conservatory after Rimsky-Korsakov's retirement in 1906,<ref>Taruskin, 73.</ref> with his son-in-law [[Maximilian Steinberg]] in charge of composition classes at the Conservatory through the 1920s.<ref>Wilson, 37.</ref> [[Dmitri Shostakovich]] would complain about Steinberg's musical conservatism, typified by such phrases as "the inviolable foundations of the ''kuchka''" and the "sacred traditions of Nikolai Andreyevich [Rimsky-Korsakov]".<ref>Letter from Shostakovich to Tatyana Glivenko dated February 26, 1924. As quoted in Fay, 24.</ref> Nor was this traditionalism limited to St. Petersburg. Well into the Soviet era, many other music conservatories remained run by traditionalists such as Ippolitov-Ivanov in Moscow and [[Reinhold Glière]] in [[Petro Tchaikovsky National Music Academy of Ukraine|Kiev]]. Because of these individuals, Maes writes, "the conservatories retained a direct link with the Belyayev aesthetic".<ref>Maes, 244.</ref>

When studying [[literature]], '''biography and its relationship to literature''' is often a subject of [[literary criticism]], and is treated in several different forms. Two scholarly approaches use [[biography]] or biographical approaches to the past as a tool for interpreting literature: '''literary biography''' and [[biographical criticism]]. Additionally, two genres of fiction rely heavily on the incorporation of biographical elements into their content, [[biographical novel|biographical fiction]] and [[autofiction|autobiographical fiction]].
==Literary biography== A literary biography is the biographical exploration of the lives of writers and artists. Biographies about artists and writers are sometimes some of the most complicated forms of biography.<ref name = backschneider1113/> Not only does the author of the biography have to write about the subject of the biography but also must incorporate discussion of the individual's literary works into the biography itself.<ref name = backschneider1113/><ref name = karl>Karl, Frederick R. "Joseph Conrad" in Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 69–88</ref> Literary biographers must balance the weight of commentary on the individual works against the biographical content to create a coherent narrative.<ref name = backschneider1113/> This balance is affected by the degree of biographical elements in an author's literary works. The close relationship between writers and their work relies on ideas that connect human psychology and literature and can be examined through [[psychoanalytic theory]].<ref name = karl/>
Literary biography tends to have a plethora of autobiographical sources. Elizabeth Longford, a biographer of [[Wilfrid Blunt]], noted, "Writers are articulate and tend to leave eloquent source material which the biographer will be eager to use."<ref name= longford>Longford, Elizabeth "Wilfrid Scawen Blunt" of Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 55-68</ref> However, some authors and artists go out of their way to discourage the writing of their biographies, as was the case with Kafka, Eliot, Orwell and Auden. Auden said, "Biographies of writers whether written by others or themselves are always superfluous and usually in bad taste.... His private life is, or should be, of no concern to anybody except himself, his family and his friends."<ref name = meyers>Meyers, Jeffrey "Introduction" in Meyers (ed.) ''The Craft'', pp 1–8</ref>
Well-received literary biographies include [[Richard Ellmann]]'s ''James Joyce'' and [[George Painter]]'s ''Marcel Proust''.<ref name = backschneider1113>Backschneider 11-13</ref><ref name = meyers/>
==Biographical criticism== {{main|Biographical criticism}} Biographical criticism is the deliberate use of biographical information to shed light on the difference created by experience between an author and his audience, and so provide insight into how to understand that particular work.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Benson| first = Jackson J| year = 1989| jstor = 25111810| title = Steinbeck: A Defense of Biographical Criticism| journal = College Literature| issue = 16| volume = 29| pages = 107–116}}</ref>
==Biographical fiction== {{see also|Biographical novel|Biographical film}} Biographical fiction is a type of [[historical fiction]] that takes a historical individual and recreates elements of his or her life, while telling a fictional narrative, usually in the genres of film or the novel. The relationship between the biographical and the fictional may vary within different pieces of biographical fiction. It frequently includes selective information and self-censoring of the past. The characters are often real people or based on real people, but the need for "truthful" representation is less strict than in [[biography]].
The various philosophies behind biographical fiction lead to different types of content. Some asserts itself as a factual narrative about the historical individual, like [[Gore Vidal]]'s ''[[Lincoln (novel)|Lincoln]]''. Other biographical fiction creates two parallel strands of narrative, one in the contemporary world and one focusing on the biographical history, such as [[Malcolm Bradbury]]'s ''[[To the Hermitage]]'' and [[Michael Cunningham]]'s ''[[The Hours (novel)|The Hours]]''. No matter what style of biographical fiction is used, the novelist usually starts the writing process with historical research.<ref name="mullan" />
Biographical fiction has its roots in late 19th and early 20th-century novels based loosely on the lives of famous people, but without direct reference to them, such as [[George Meredith]]'s ''[[Diana of the Crossways]]'' (1885) and [[Somerset Maugham]]'s ''[[The Moon and Sixpence]]'' (1919). During the early part of the 20th century this became a distinct genre, with novels that were explicitly about individuals' lives.<ref name = mullan>{{cite news| title = Heavy on the source John Mullan analyses The Master by Colm Tóibín. Week three: biographical fiction| first = John| last = Mullan| newspaper =The Guardian| date = 30 April 2005| url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2005/apr/30/fiction.colmtoibin}}</ref>
==Autobiographical fiction== {{main|Autofiction}} {{see also|Autobiographical novel|Autobiographical comics}} Autobiographical fiction, or autofiction, is fiction that incorporates the author's own experience into the narrative. It allows authors to both rely and reflect on their own experience. However, the reading of the autobiographical fiction need not always be associated with the author. Such books may be treated as distinct fictional works.<ref name = bragg>{{cite news| url = http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/books/article5668638.ece| newspaper = The Sunday Times| date = 8 February 2009| title = Melvyn Bragg on autobiographical fiction| accessdate = 9 June 2011}}</ref>

A '''character arc''' is the transformation or inner journey<ref name="Gerke">{{harvtxt|Gerke|2010|p=79}}</ref> of a [[character (arts)|character]] over the course of a story. If a story has a character arc, the character begins as one sort of person and gradually transforms into a different sort of person in response to changing developments in the story. Since the change is often substantive and leading from one personality trait to a diametrically opposite trait (for example, from greed to benevolence), the geometric term ''[[Arc (geometry)|arc]]'' is often used to describe the sweeping change. In most stories, [[main character|lead characters]] and [[protagonist]]s are the characters most likely to experience character arcs,<ref name="Bell">{{harvtxt|Bell|2004|p=142}}</ref> although it is possible for lesser characters to change as well.<ref name="Gerke" /> A driving element of the [[Plot (narrative)|plot]]s of many stories is that the main character seems initially unable to overcome opposing forces, possibly because they lack skills or knowledge or resources or friends. To overcome such obstacles, the protagonist must change, possibly by learning new skills, to arrive at a higher sense of self-awareness or capability. Protagonists can achieve such self-awareness by interacting with their environment, by enlisting the help of mentors, by changing their viewpoint, or by some other method.
==Dramatic narrative structure== {{main|Dramatic structure}} Throughout the trajectory of narratives with a tripartite structure, character arcs often unfold beside the narrative arc in the following way:
===First act=== During the first act, the character arc is established or re-established for at least one character, the main character (the protagonist), within the exposition (noument) of the environment including relationships to other characters. Later in the first act, a dynamic, on-screen incident, known as the [[Inciting Incident|inciting incident]], or catalyst occurs that confronts the protagonist, whose attempts to deal with this incident lead to a second and more dramatic situation, known as the first [[Climax (narrative)|turning point]]. After the first turning point, life will never be the same for the protagonist and raises a dramatic question that will be answered in the climax of the story. The dramatic question should be framed in terms of the protagonist's call to action, for example, Will X recover the diamond? Will Y get the girl? Will Z capture the killer?<ref name=bible>{{harvtxt|Trottier|2010}}</ref>
===Second act=== During the second act, also referred to as "[[rising action]]", the character arc develops as the protagonist attempts to resolve the problem initiated by the first turning point, only to discover ever-worsening situations, which often lead to the learning of new skills, the discovery of capabilities, and (sometimes late in the second act if at all) the raising of self-awareness.<ref name=bible />
===Third act=== During the third act, including the climax, "[[falling action]]" and resolution (denouement), the narrative arc is completed although the character arc typically is not. During the climax, because the main tensions of the story are brought to their most intense point and the dramatic question is answered, a character arc reaches a place where the character gains a new sense of who they are becoming. As the plot and its subplots resolve, the character arc's emphasis shifts from the learning of any new skills or the discovery of dormant capabilities to the awakening of a higher level of self-awareness, which in turn changes who the character is becoming.<ref name=bible />
== Examples ==
=== In literature === Some examples include:
* [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Hamlet]]'' sees the eponymous character, once a young scholarly prince full of promise, quickly becoming a melancholic brooder after his father's death. The play shows his slow but deadly fall into madness. * In [[Dostoevsky]]'s ''[[Crime and Punishment]]'', the protagonist [[Raskolnikov]] commits a murder, that leads him on a path of redemption, and after an intense inner struggle, he realizes that he needs to be punished for his actions, reporting himself to the authorities. * [[Victor Hugo]]'s ''[[Les Misérables]]'' includes a myriad of characters that transform against the backdrop of social events. [[Jean Valjean]] starts as a selfish, violent convict and develops into a generous and loving father to [[Cosette]], who in turn transforms from an abused, lonely and somewhat secluded child to a beautiful and caring woman. * [[Ursula Le Guin]]'s protagonist from her ''[[A Wizard of Earthsea]]'' quartet gradually changes from an impulsive and arrogant youth to a stoic and wise man, reconciling the darkness within and all the bad actions it had caused. * ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' series of books by [[George R.R. Martin]] shows numerous examples of complete character arcs. [[Daenerys Targaryen]] transforms from a naive young girl to a queen and a conqueror, only to fall from grace after a misuse of power. The character of [[Jon Snow (character)|Jon Snow]], undergoes a similar arc of embracing the need to govern and rule and metaphorically "kills the boy and lets the man be born" only to die after a misuse of power. Other characters such as [[Sansa Stark]] and [[Jaime Lannister]], start out as childish and petty, but once faced with the cruelty of the world, Jaime grows into a mature and wise leader, and Sansa grows into a strong-willed and poised lady.
=== In film === Some examples include:
* In ''[[Tootsie]]'', [[Dustin Hoffman]]'s character begins as a [[misogynist]]ic [[chauvinist]] but when he is forced to play the part of a woman, he also experiences a change in how he views women and becomes a different character by the end. * In ''[[Empire of the Sun (film)|Empire of the Sun]]'', Jim begins as a carefree young boy. After the Japanese take over [[Shanghai]] and he is separated from his family, he is forced to suffer trauma because of the war. * In ''[[The Godfather]]'' (1972), widely regarded as one of the [[greatest films ever made]], Michael Corleone initially wants nothing to do with the crime business of his father, Don Vito Corleone. When Vito is critically injured in a shooting, however, Michael gradually becomes more involved in a war of retribution on those responsible. This, effectively and ironically, sets him down the path to becoming Don of the Corleone crime syndicate. Its acclaimed sequel, ''[[The Godfather Part II]]'' (1974), chronicles Michael's effective fall from grace as a result of becoming a powerful crime lord. * In ''[[Taxi Driver]]'' (1976), Travis Bickle degenerates from a somewhat disturbed, highly disorganized Vietnam war veteran into an obsessive psychotic. * In ''[[Goodfellas]]'' (1990), [[Henry Hill]] (played by [[Ray Liotta]]) goes from being a suave and sophisticated gangster to a paranoid nervous wreck due to a severe [[cocaine]] addiction. * In ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'', [[Elsa (Disney)|Elsa]] begins the movie embracing her ice powers. After injuring her sister [[Anna (Disney)|Anna]] she becomes scared of her powers and considers herself a monster. After her sister sacrifices herself, Elsa finally embraces her powers again. Anna begins the movie as a social butterfly willing to throw herself into any man's arms. After [[Hans (Disney)|Hans]] betrays her, Anna learns that looks can sometimes be deceiving. *In ''[[Thor: Ragnarok]]'', the [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]] begins a story arc dealing with accepting himself as one person rather than seeing Bruce Banner separate. It continues in ''[[Avengers: Infinity War]]'' and will conclude in ''[[Untitled Avengers film|Avengers 4]]''.
=== In television === Like a [[story arc]], which often is composed of many [[dramatic structure|narrative arcs]], the character arc is not confined within the limits of one narrative. The character arc may extend over to the next story, a [[sequel]], or another episode. In episodic [[TV series]], the character arc functions as a [[narrative hook]] that writers often use to ensure viewers continue watching.
* The TV series ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'' made heavy use of character arcs throughout its run, with story arcs (or mysteries, as the show was famed for) normally being used to move the plot along in the background, as the four protagonists, [[Susan Mayer]], [[Lynette Scavo]], [[Bree Van de Kamp]], and [[Gabrielle Solis]], dealt with their various foibles and flaws, through the eyes of their dead friend and neighbour, [[Mary Alice Young]]. * Over the course of the television series ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' (first US air date: {{start date|1995|9}}), [[Gabrielle (Xena)|Gabrielle]] starts from a young, idealistic Greek farm girl to becoming a warrior, and in the end, she becomes [[Xena]]'s successor.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} *''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]'' focuses on character arcs for each of the survivors of a plane crash. [[Jack Shephard]] accepting his role as protector of the island, [[James "Sawyer" Ford]] going from a self-centered con-man to a mature leader, [[John Locke (Lost)|John Locke]]'' discovering his destiny on the island.
* ''[[Smallville (TV series)|Smallville]]'' (first US air date: {{start date|2001|10}}) focuses on character arcs for each of its main characters as they progress into their ''[[Superman]]'' comic book identities. [[Clark Kent]]'s arc revolved around the gradual acceptance of his destiny and becoming a hero. The series also tracks [[Lex Luthor]]'s progression into darkness and [[Lois Lane]]'s emulation of her cousin [[Chloe Sullivan|Chloe]] as she becomes a hardened journalist. Other characters have their eventual character arc alluded to but never explicitly defined or realized onscreen, such as [[Perry White]]'s rise to editor of the ''[[Daily Planet]]'' and [[Lex Luthor]]'s ascension to [[President of the United States]]. As well as individual characters, there are arcs involving many characters which intertwine to tell about the formation of the [[Justice League]].{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} *In ''[[Breaking Bad]],'' [[Walter White (Breaking Bad)|Walter White]] begins as a high school chemistry teacher struggling with a serious illness while trying to support his family financially. His decision to become a manufacturer of addictive illegal drugs starts a downward spiral in which his wife, [[Skyler White]], divorces him, and his character ''arcs'' from a morally responsible regular guy into a dangerous monster. * The teen drama series ''[[13 Reasons Why]]'' features two character arcs for its protagonist Clay Jensen: In the flashbacks, Clay begins as a shy young man until meeting [[Hannah Baker]]. In the present, after Hannah's death, he becomes emotionally withdrawn until listening to the tapes left behind by his former friend. After learning the truth, he becomes a warrior and a voice of justice for Hannah.

[[King of Sweden|The King of Sweden]] |year_adopted = 1448
November 17, 1905 |supporters = two lions regardant, crowned and with forked tails (queue fourchée) Or armed gules, standing on a compartment Or |shield = Azure, quartered by a cross Or with outbent arms, and an inescutcheon containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three open crowns Or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams argent, a lion crowned with an open crown Or armed gules. The inescutcheon is party per pale the arms for the House of Vasa (Bendwise azure, argent and gules, a vasa (sheaf of wheat) Or); and the House of Bernadotte (Azure, issuant from a wavy base a bridge with three arches and two towers embattled argent, in honour point an eagle regardant with wings inverted resting on thunderbolts Or, and in chief the Big Dipper constellation of the same). |crest = Royal Crown of Sweden |orders = [[Order of Seraphim]] |compartment = Pedestal Or |other_elements = All surrounded by ermine mantling, crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseladorned strings Or |earlier_versions = |use = }} {{Infobox coat of arms |name = Lesser coat of arms of the Kingdom of Sweden |country = Sweden |image = Coat of arms of Sweden (shield and chain).svg |image_width = 120 |lesser = Coat of arms of Sweden.svg |lesser_width = 75 |lesser_caption = Version without the Order of the Seraphim |armiger = The [[Riksdag]]
[[Government of Sweden]]
[[King of Sweden]] |year_adopted = 1336{{cite journal |last=Loÿe |first=Georges de |title=Om ursprunget till det svenska riksvapnet Tre Kronor |year=1986 |journal=Heraldisk tidsskrift |volume=1986 |issue=6 |pages=54, 155–174 : ill. |id=0440-6966 |issn=0440-6966 |language=sv}}
November 17, 1905 |shield = Azure, three coronets Or, placed two above one |crest = Royal Crown of Sweden |orders = [[Order of Seraphim]] |use = }} The '''coat of arms of the [[Kingdom of Sweden]]''' ({{lang-sv|Sveriges riksvapen}}) has a lesser and a greater version. == Regulated usage == The usage of the coats of arms is regulated by Swedish Law, [[Swedish Code of Statutes|Act]] [http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/19700498.HTM 1970:498], which states (in unofficial translation) that "in commercial activities, the coats of arms, the flag or other official insignia of Sweden may not be used in a trademark or other insignias for products or services without proper authorisation. This includes any mark or text referring to the Swedish State which this can give the commercial mark a sign of official endorsement. This includes municipal coats of arms which are registered." Any representation consisting of three crowns ordered two above one are considered to be the lesser coat of arms, and its usage is therefore restricted by law 1970:498. ==Variants== The arms of Sweden were first formally codified by law in 1908.{{cite web|url=http://runeberg.org/rikskal/1909/0002.html|title=i (Svensk rikskalender / 1909)|website=Runeberg.org|accessdate=9 January 2018}} This law also formally codifies the differences between the "greater" and "lesser" arms. The present law prescribing the two arms dates from 1982. ===Greater version=== The greater coat of arms is blazoned in Swedish law as follows:
''A shield [[azure (heraldry)|azure]], quartered by a cross [[Or (heraldry)|Or]] with outbent arms, and an [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|inescutcheon]] containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three [[Crown (heraldry)|open crowns]] Or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams [[argent]], a [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] crowned with an open crown Or armed [[gules]]. The inescutcheon is [[Division of the field|party per pale]] the arms for the [[House of Vasa]] (Bendwise azure, argent and gules, a ''vasa'' Or); and the [[House of Bernadotte]] (Azure, issuant from a wavy base a bridge with three arches and two towers embattled argent, in honor point an eagle regardant with wings inverted resting on thunderbolts Or, and in chief the Big Dipper constellation of the same). The main shield is crowned by a royal crown and surrounded by the insignia of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]. [[Supporters|Supported]] by two lions regardant, crowned and with forked tails Or armed gules, standing on a [[Compartment (heraldry)|compartment]] Or. All surrounded by [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] mantling, crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseladorned strings Or.''Original text of Swedish statute 1982:268, 2 §, states: ''Stora riksvapnet utgörs av en blå huvudsköld, kvadrerad genom ett kors av guld med utböjda armar, samt en hjärtsköld som innehåller det kungliga husets dynastivapen. Huvudsköldens första och fjärde fält innehåller tre öppna kronor av guld, ordnade två över en. Huvudsköldens andra och tredje fält innehåller tre ginbalksvis gående strömmar av silver, överlagda med ett upprest, med öppen krona krönt lejon av guld med röd tunga samt röda tänder och klor. Hjärtskölden är kluven. Första fältet innehåller Vasaättens vapen: ett i blått, silver och rött styckat fält, belagt med en vase av guld. Andra fältet innehåller ätten Bernadottes vapen: i blått fält en ur vatten uppskjutande bro med tre valv och två krenelerade torn, allt av silver, däröver en örn av guld med vänstervänt huvud och sänkta vingar gripande om en åskvigg av guld samt överst Karlavagnens stjärnbild av guld. Huvudskölden är krönt med en kunglig krona och omges av Serafimer ordens insignier. Sköldhållare är två tillbakaseende, med kunglig krona krönta lejon med kluvna svansar samt röda tungor, tänder och klor. Lejonen står på ett postament av guld. Det hela omges av en med kunglig krona krönt hermelinsfodrad vapenmantel av purpur med frans av guld och uppknuten med tofsprydda snören av guld. Stora riksvapnet får brukas även utan ordensinsignier, sköldhållare, postament eller vapenmantel.'' {{cite web |url= http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/19820268.HTM |title= Lag (1982:268) om Sveriges riksvapen |accessdate=2008-06-27 |work= Swedish Code of Statutes |publisher= [[Sveriges Riksdag]] |date= 1982-04-29 |language= Swedish}}
The greater arms may also be displayed only with the crowned escutcheon. While the arms have undergone significant changes over the years, such as changing the inescutcheon with the ruling dynasty, they are based on arms created by King [[Charles VIII of Sweden|Karl Knutsson]] in 1448.{{cite web |url= http://www.riksarkivet.se/default.aspx?id=1268&ptid=0 |title= Stora riksvapnet |language= Swedish |publisher= Swedish National Archives |date= 2011-12-20 |accessdate=2012-01-29}} The [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] used in the greater blazon has in total five elements: 4 [[Quartering (heraldry)|quarterings]] on the main escutcheon (two coats of arms duplicated), and three coat of arms incorporated into an escutcheon of pretense. However, Bernadotte never used any stars in the arms of Pontecorvo (neither as Prince of Pontecorvo, nor as King of Sweden and Norway). The stars were introduced as an element in the royal coat of arms in the 19th century,{{cite book |last=Berghman |first=Arvid |title=Dynastien Bernadottes vapen och det svenska riksvapnet |series=Skrifter / utgivna av Riksheraldikerämbetet, 99-2298099-1 ; 1 |year=1944 |publisher=Svensk litteratur |location=Stockholm |language=sv}} chosen as a symbol of Sweden's eternal existence, as in the poem by [[Esaias Tegnér]]: {{quote|As long as [[Charles's Wain]] still turns, Its golden wheels around the Northern zone, As long as the land still produces iron and heroes, Intact shall stand the ancient Swedish throne.}} This symbol became especially popular through its allusion to the name that had been borne by so many famous Swedish kings. [[Ursa Major]], or as it is called in Swedish, ''Karlavagnen'' (Charles' Wain), adds a Swedish accent to the Bernadotte dynastic coat of arms much in the same way as do the Vasa arms.{{cite web|url=http://www.theheraldrysociety.com/articles/early_history_of_heraldry/the_three_crowns_of_sweden.htm|title=The Heraldry Society|website=Theheraldrysociety.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} {{familytree/start |White box with three children Red box, Green box, Blue box, all married to each other}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |finish| | | | |finish=[[File:Great shield of arms of Sweden.svg|120px]]}} {{familytree|border=0| |,|-|-|-|+|-|-|-|.| }} {{familytree|border=0|CROWN| |BJELB| |BERN |CROWN=[[File:Shield of arms of Sweden.svg|120px]]
The [[three Crowns|three crowns]]|BJELB=[[File:Arms of Bjelbo.svg|120px]]
[[House of Bjelbo]]|BERN=[[File:Arms of Bernadotte.svg|120px]]
[[House of Bernadotte]]}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | | | | |,|-|'| }} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |VASA|^|PONT |VASA=[[File:Arms of Vasa.svg|120px]]
The [[House of Vasa]]|PONT=[[File:Coat of Arms of Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte.svg|150x150px]]
Arms of [[Charles XIV John of Sweden|Jean Baptiste Jules Bernadotte]]
as prince of [[Ponte Corvo]]
and [[Marshal of France]]
(later Charles XIV of Sweden)}} {{familytree|border=0| | | | | | | |,|-|'| }} {{familytree|border=0| | | | |VASA|^|PONT |VASA=[[File:Arms of the French Empire3.svg|120px]]
[[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]]|PONT=
[[Ponte Corvo]]}} {{familytree/end}} [[File:Personal command-sign of the King of Sweden.svg|thumb|left|The personal command sign, for military use, of the King is a rendition of the emblazonment of the greater arms. Introduced by royal regulation in 1943, it has only been created once.]] The arms are supported by two lions with forked tails (''queue fourchée''), facing away from the shield and crowned with Royal Crowns. For centuries, the lion has been an important element in Swedish heraldry and especially for the State Coat of Arms. The shield may be surmounted by the Collar of the [[Order of Seraphim]], the foremost order in Sweden, and the highest honour the Swedish state can bestow on an individual.See sections 2 and 3, Lag No. 268 om Sveriges Riksvapen of April 29, 1982. Besides being the official national coat of arms, the greater coat of arms is also the personal coat of arms of the king, and as such he can decree its use as a personal coat of arms by other members of the [[House of Bernadotte|Royal House]], with the alterations and additions decided by him. [[Blazon]]: "The greater state arms consist of a head shield azure, quartered by a cross or with outbent arms, and an [[inescutcheon]] containing the dynastic arms of the Royal House. In the first and fourth fields three coronets or, placed two above one. In the second and third fields three sinisterbendwise streams argent, a lion crowned with an open crown or with armaments gules. The inescutcheon is party per pale the arms for the [[House of Vasa]] and the [[House of Bernadotte]]. The main shield is crowned by a royal crown and surrounded by the insignia of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]. Supported by two lions regardant or crowned, with parted tails and armaments gules, standing on a postament. All surrounded by hermine mantling crowned with a royal crown and tied up with tasseled strings or." ===Lesser version=== The lesser coat of arms is mainly used by the [[Government of Sweden]] and subordinate government authorities. As such it may be joined by insignias symbolising the activity of individual government agencies, following approval by the State Board of Heraldry. It is, for instance, embroidered on all [[Swedish police]] uniforms and in various coats of arms of the [[Swedish Armed Forces]]. Blazon: "Azure, with three coronets Or, ordered two above one." Crowned with a royal crown. The shield may also be surrounded by the insignias of the [[Order of the Seraphim]]." ===Royal Family=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Coat of arms !! Sweden.svg|170px]] || [[Queen Silvia of Sweden|Silvia, Queen of Sweden]] |- style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Coat of arms of Crown Princess Victoria, Duchess of Västergötland.svg|120px]] || Duke of Värmland.svg|120px]]|| [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland]] |- style="text-align:center;" |[[File:Coat of arms of Prince Alexander, Duke of Södermanland.svg|120px]]||[[Prince Alexander,
