revision.comment: /* top */ Removed PETA from lead; it's worth mentioning further down, but not important enough for the lead
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Natascha Kampusch |website = http://natascha-kampusch.at |image = |caption = |birth_name = Natascha Maria Kampusch |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1988|02|17}} |birth_place = [[Vienna]], Austria |disappeared_date = {{disappeared date and age|df=yes|1998|03|02|1988|02|17}} |disappeared_place = Vienna, Austria |disappeared_status = Found alive {{disappeared date and age|df=yes|2006|08|23|1988|02|17}} |other_names = |known_for = [[Kidnapping|Kidnap]] survivor |occupation = |nationality = }} '''Natascha Maria Kampusch''' (born 17 February 1988) is an Austrian woman who was [[Child abduction|abducted]] at the age of 10 on 2 March 1998 and held in a secret [[Basement|cellar]] by her [[Kidnapping|kidnapper]] [[Wolfgang Přiklopil]] for more than eight years, until she escaped on 23 August 2006. She has written a book about her ordeal, ''3,096 Days'' (2010), upon which the 2013 German film ''[[3096]]'' is based.
== Early years and family == Kampusch was raised by her mother, Brigitta Sirny (née Kampusch), and her father, Ludwig Koch, in [[Vienna]], Austria. Her early life with her mother was reportedly not a happy one, according to Ludwig Adamovich, head of a special commission looking into possible police failures in the investigation of the kidnapping. He claimed that "the time Kampusch was imprisoned might have been better for her than what she experienced before", a statement absolutely denied by Brigitta Sirny, who threatened to sue the commission chief over his remarks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austriantimes.at/news/General_News/2009-08-05/15306/Kampusch_mum_may_sue_commission_chief |title=Kampusch mum may sue commission chief – General News – Austrian Times Online News – English Newspaper |publisher=Austriantimes.at |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref>
Her family included two adult sisters, and five nieces and nephews. Sirny and Koch separated while Kampusch was still a child and divorced after her abduction. Kampusch spent time with both of them, and had returned to her mother's home from a holiday with Koch the day before her kidnapping.<ref>{{cite news | first= Roger | last= Boyes | author= | url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/world/europe/article2599973.ece | title= Natascha: I ignored omens on day of my kidnap | work= | publisher= [[The Times|Times Online]] | pages= | page= | date= 7 September 2006 | accessdate= 7 September 2006 | location= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,434374,00.html | title= Entführer täuschte Lösegeld-Erpressung vor | work= | publisher= [[Der Spiegel|Der Spiegel Online]] | pages= | page= | date= 30 August 2006 | accessdate= 8 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060902030119/http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0%2C1518%2C434374%2C00.html|archivedate=2 September 2006 |language=de}}</ref>
== Kidnapping == The 10-year-old Kampusch left her family's residence in [[Vienna]]'s [[Donaustadt]] district on the morning of 2 March 1998, but failed to arrive at school or come home. A 12-year-old witness reported having seen her being dragged into a white minibus by two men,<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://rawstory.com/news/2006/Further_details_emerge_of_Austrian__08252006.html | title= Further details emerge of Austrian kidnapping case | work= | publisher= [[The Raw Story]] | pages= | page= | date= 25 August 2006 | accessdate= 30 August 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061026073523/http://rawstory.com/news/2006/Further_details_emerge_of_Austrian__08252006.html |archivedate = 26 October 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/panorama/417/315310/text/|title=Fall Kampusch wird neu aufgerollt|publisher=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] (online)|date=24 October 2008|accessdate=24 October 2008|language=de|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028060839/http://www.sueddeutsche.de/panorama/417/315310/text/|archive-date=28 October 2008|dead-url=yes}}</ref> although Kampusch did not report a second man being present.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article621640.ece |title=Translation of Natascha Kampusch's letter |publisher=[[Times Online]] |date=28 August 2008 | location=London | accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> A massive police effort followed in which 776 minivans were examined,<ref>[http://www.bild.t-online.de/BTO/news/2007/08/07/kampusch-serie/natascha-mutter-spricht-teil3,geo=2265612.html So ließ die Polizei Nataschas Entführer laufen] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071203091802/http://www.bild.t-online.de/BTO/news/2007/08/07/kampusch-serie/natascha-mutter-spricht-teil3,geo=2265612.html |date=3 December 2007 }} T-Online extract from Sirny's book, German</ref><ref>[http://www.20min.ch/news/dossier/kampusch/story/19610744 «Wer fotografiert seine Tochter nackt mit einer Peitsche?»] 20min.ch Interview with the primary Police investigator Max Edelbacher, German</ref> including that of her kidnapper, Přiklopil, who lived about half an hour from Vienna by car in the [[Lower Austria]]n town of [[Strasshof an der Nordbahn]], near [[Gänserndorf]]. Although he stated that on the morning of the kidnapping he was alone at home, the police were satisfied with his explanation that he was using the minibus to transport rubble from the construction of his home.<ref name="Kurier25514">{{cite news|title=Er war ein Teil meines Lebens |url=http://www.kurier.at/nachrichten/chronik/25514.php |work=[[Kurier]] |date=29 August 2006 |accessdate=29 August 2006 |language=German |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901102957/http://www.kurier.at/nachrichten/chronik/25514.php |archivedate=1 September 2006 }}</ref><!-- Wolfgang Přiklopil, der als Besitzer eines weißen Kastenwagens wie viele andere Kleinbusbesitzer ins Visier der Fahnder geraten war, wurde seinerzeit von der Polizei gefragt, was er am Morgen des 2. März 1998 —dem Tag, an dem Natascha Kampusch entführt wurde— gemacht habe. Seine Antwort: Er sei alleine daheim gewesen. Den Beamten erschien das glaubwürdig, zumal der Mann zu Hause offensichtlich gerade mit Umbauarbeiten beschäftigt war. in: http://www.salzburg.com/sn/nachrichten/artikel/2332298.html -->
Speculations of [[child pornography]] rings or [[organ theft]] were offered,<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/oesterreich/99923/Jahrelang-Spekulationen-um-Natascha | title= Jahrelang Spekulationen um Natascha | work= | publisher= [[Die Presse]] | pages= | page= | date= 24 August 2006 | accessdate= 25 January 2012 |language=de}}</ref> leading officials to also investigate possible links to the crimes of the French serial killer [[Michel Fourniret]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://service.spiegel.de/cache/international/0,1518,433349,00.html |title=Missing Austrian Girl Resurfaces After Eight Years |publisher= [[Der Spiegel|Spiegel Online International]] |date=24 August 2006 |accessdate=6 September 2006}}</ref> Because Kampusch had carried her passport with her when she left (she had been on a family trip to [[Hungary]] a few days before), the police extended the search abroad. Accusations against Kampusch's family complicated the issue even more.<ref>{{cite news |first = Tony |last = Paterson |author = |url = http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article2362765.ece |title = Kampusch mother accused of kidnap to hide sex abuse |work = |publisher = [[The Independent]] |pages = |page = |date = 16 March 2007 |accessdate = 24 March 2007 |location = London |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070319182548/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article2362765.ece |archivedate = 19 March 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Captivity === During the eight years of her captivity, Kampusch was held in a small cellar underneath Přiklopil's garage. The entrance was concealed behind a cupboard. The cellar only had {{convert|5|sqm}} of space. It had a door made of concrete and was reinforced with steel. The room had no windows and was soundproof.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5285048.stm | title = Inside the Austrian girl's 'dungeon' | publisher = BBC Online | date=25 August 2006}}</ref> For the first six months of her captivity, Kampusch was not allowed to leave the chamber at any time, and for several years of her captivity she was not allowed to leave the tiny space at night. Afterwards, she spent increasing amounts of time upstairs in the rest of the house, but each night was sent back to the chamber to sleep, as well as while Přiklopil was at work.
In later years, she was seen outside in the garden alone,<ref>{{cite news|first=William J. |last= Kole |url=http://www.northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkyNiZmZ2JlbDdmN3ZxZWVFRXl5NTMxNDk1MiZ5cmlyeTdmNzE3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTY= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514045312/http://www.northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkyNiZmZ2JlbDdmN3ZxZWVFRXl5NTMxNDk1MiZ5cmlyeTdmNzE3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTY= |archivedate=14 May 2007 |title=Neighbors say they saw captive girl alone outside|publisher=NorthJersey.com|date=30 August 2006|accessdate=4 September 2006}}</ref> and Přiklopil's business partner has said that Kampusch seemed relaxed and happy when she and Přiklopil called at his home to borrow a trailer.<ref>{{cite news |first= Michael |last = Leidig |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,13509-2335782,00.html |title=Kidnapper's friend says he met 'cheerful' Natascha |publisher=The Times |date=31 August 2006 |accessdate=2 September 2006 | location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227130950/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article623344.ece |archive-date=27 February 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://oesterreich.orf.at/wien/stories/133065|title=Die Erklärung von Ernst H. im Wortlaut (The explanation by Ernst Holzapfel in his wording)|publisher=[[ORF (broadcaster)]] (online)|date=30 August 2006 |accessdate=1 October 2006|language=de}}</ref><!--important--> After her eighteenth birthday, she was allowed to leave the house with Přiklopil, but her kidnapper threatened to kill her if she made any noise.<ref>{{cite news |first= Michael |last= Leidig |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,13509-2337830,00.html|title=Natascha tells of abductor's violence and terrifying lies|publisher=The Times|date=1 September 2006|accessdate=2 September 2006 | location=London}}</ref> He later took her on a skiing trip to a resort near Vienna for a few hours. She initially denied that they had made the trip, but eventually admitted that it was true, although she said she had no chance to escape during that time.<ref>{{cite news | first = Michael | last = Leidig | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1529016/I-went-on-ski-holiday-with-my-kidnapper-admits-Natascha.html|title = I went on ski holiday with my kidnapper, admits Natascha|publisher = The Daily Telegraph|date=16 September 2006|accessdate=16 September 2006 | location=London}}</ref>
According to Kampusch's official statement after her escape, she and Přiklopil would get up early each morning to have breakfast together. Přiklopil gave her books, so she educated herself.<!-- important: http://www.stern.de/politik/deutschland/:Fall-Kampusch-Verlies-Schule/569880.html --> Later, when explaining that in general she did not feel she had missed anything during her imprisonment, she noted, "I spared myself many things, I did not start smoking or drinking and I did not hang out in bad company". But she also said: "I always had the thought: surely I didn't come into the world so I could be locked up and my life completely ruined. I give up in despair about this unfairness. I always felt like a poor chicken in a hen house. You saw my dungeon on television and in the media. Thus you know how small it was. It was a place to despair."<ref name="despair">[[Sydney Morning Herald]], 7 September 2006. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/it-was-a-place-to-despair/2006/09/07/1157222229739.html It was a place to despair: kidnap girl]". Accessed 7 September 2006.</ref> <!-- ...Also wissen Sie, wie klein es war. Es war zum Verzweifeln. in: WAZ-interview http://www.waz.de/waz/waz.homepage3_115876.php or NEWS-interview http://www.lansky.at/fileadmin/content/PDF/n_kampusch_in_news.PDF ...see also: Kronen Zeitung interview http://www.lansky.at/fileadmin/content/PDF/natascha_kampusch_i_krone.pdf --> She was given a television and radio to pass the time with, although she was initially only allowed to watch taped programmes and listen to foreign radio stations so she would not be aware of the publicised search for her.<ref name="3096 days">{{cite book|author=Natascha Kampusch|author2=Heike Gronemeier |author3=Corinna Milborn |title=3,096 Days|date=September 2010|publisher=Penguin}}</ref> At one point, she tried to escape by jumping out of a car.<ref name="despair" />
A large portion of Kampusch's time upstairs was spent doing housework for Přiklopil and cooking for him.<ref name="3096 days" /> Dietmar Ecker, Kampusch's media advisor, said Kampusch told him Přiklopil "would beat her so badly she could hardly walk. When she was beaten black and blue, he tried to smarten her up. Then he would take his camera and photograph her".<ref>{{cite news|first=Tony|last=Paterson|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article1655648.ece|title=Mother of Austrian kidnap survivor 'knew abductor|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=21 September 2006|accessdate=21 September 2006|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060921152538/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article1655648.ece|archive-date=21 September 2006|dead-url=yes}}<!-- also republished at http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/story.jsp?story=707203 --></ref> <!-- original source: War sie nicht ordentlich genug, verprügelte er sie so heftig, dass sie kaum noch gehen konnte. Wenn sie grün und blau geschlagen war, versuchte er sie wieder herzurichten. Dann nahm er seine Kamera und fotografierte sie.; in: Stern, 21 September 2006, page 74; see also: War Přiklopil mit ihrer Arbeit nicht zufrieden, schlug er Natascha grün und blau.; in: http://www.stern.de/politik/panorama/:Natascha-Kampusch-Priklopil/570677.html; and media-manager Dietmar Ecker (giving up): Ich habe in die Hölle geguckt (I looked in the hell) --> According to her autobiography, as part of her abuse, Přiklopil would starve her to make her physically weak, therefore unable to escape. Her [[Body mass index|body mass index (BMI)]] had reached as low as 14.8 during captivity (normal BMI: 18.5 to 25).<ref name="3096 days" />
Přiklopil had warned Kampusch that the doors and windows of the house were booby-trapped with high explosives. He also claimed to be carrying a gun and that he would kill her and the neighbours if she attempted to escape.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=928|title=The First Post: Victim or villain: Austria decides|publisher=The First Post|date=20 September 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012223116/http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=928|archivedate=12 October 2006}}</ref> Nevertheless, Kampusch on one occasion fantasized about chopping his head off with an axe, although she quickly dismissed the idea.<ref name="b" /> She also attempted to make noise during her early years of captivity by throwing bottles of water against the walls.<ref name="b" /> She said that on trips out with Přiklopil, she had attempted to attract attention, but in vain.<ref name="b">{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5319214.stm | title=Girl relives kidnap ordeal on TV | publisher=[[BBC News Online]] | date=7 September 2006 | accessdate=23 August 2007}}</ref>
=== Escape === The 18-year-old Kampusch reappeared on 23 August 2006. At 12:53 pm, when Kampusch was cleaning and vacuuming her kidnapper's [[BMW 850]]i automobile in the garden, Přiklopil got a call on his mobile phone. Because of the vacuuming noise, he walked away to take the call. Kampusch left the vacuum cleaner running and ran away, unseen by Přiklopil, who, according to the caller, completed the phone call without any sign of being disturbed or distracted. Kampusch ran for some 200 metres through gardens and a street, jumping fences, and asking passers-by to call the police, but they paid her no attention. After about five minutes, she knocked on the window of a 71-year-old neighbour known as Inge T, saying, "I am Natascha Kampusch".<ref name="elkins">{{cite news |first = Ruth |last = Elkins |title = Natascha's survival is due to her young age and 'iron will' |url = http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article1222032.ece |publisher = [[The Independent Online]] |date = 27 August 2006 |accessdate = 27 August 2006 |location = London |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060830212216/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article1222032.ece |archivedate = 30 August 2006 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The neighbour called the police, who arrived at 1:04 pm. Later, Kampusch was taken to the police station in the town of [[Deutsch-Wagram]].
Kampusch was identified by a [[scar]] on her body, by her passport (which was found in the room where she had been held), and by DNA tests.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5285290.stm | title= Austria girl 'describes kidnap' | work= | publisher= BBC News | pages= | page= | date= 25 August 2006 | accessdate= 27 August 2006 }}</ref> She was in good physical health{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} , although Kampusch looked pale and shaken and weighed only {{convert|48|kg|lbs|abbr=on}}<!-- source: newspaper Bild am Sonntag, 17 September 2006, her father Ludwig Koch: http://www.bild.t-online.de/BTO/news/aktuell/2006/09/17/natascha-kampusch/natascha-kampusch-beschimpfung.html -->; she weighed {{convert|45|kg|lbs|abbr=on}} when she disappeared eight years earlier. Kampusch grew only {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} during her captivity.
Sabine Freudenberger, the first police officer to speak to Kampusch after her ordeal, said that she was astonished by her "intelligence, her [[vocabulary]]". After two years, Přiklopil had brought her books, newspapers and a radio, which she kept tuned mainly to [[Ö1 International|Ö1]], an [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]] station that is known for promoting education and classical music. She also states that she constantly had a feeling that she lacked something: "a deficit. So I wanted to make that better and I tried to educate myself, to teach myself skills. I have learned to knit for example."<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,3-2345787,00.html Transcript: Natascha Kampusch TV interview]: '''Times Online'''. 6 September 2006. Retrieved 15 September 2006.</ref>
Přiklopil, knowing that the police were after him, killed himself by jumping in front of a [[Vienna S-Bahn|suburban train]] near the [[Wien Nord]] station in [[Vienna]]. He had apparently planned to commit suicide rather than be caught, having told Kampusch that "they would not catch him alive".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/08/25/wcaptive25.xml |title=Held captive by 'the master', she lost her childhood in a tiny room |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=25 August 2006|accessdate=27 August 2006 | location=London | first=Kate | last=Connolly}}</ref>
==Kidnapper== {{Infobox criminal | name = Wolfgang Přiklopil | image = | image_size = 175px | caption = Passport photograph of Přiklopil{{deletable image-caption|Tuesday, 16 May 2017|F6}} | birth_date = {{birth date|1962|5|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vienna]], Austria | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|2006|8|23|1962|5|14}} | death_place = [[Vienna]], Austria | cause = [[Suicide]] by jumping in front of train | nationality = | occupation = Telecommunications technician | partner = | children = an anonymous daughter (alleged) | parents = Karl and Waltraud Přiklopil | motive = | conviction status = Deceased }} '''Wolfgang Přiklopil''' (14 May 1962 – 23 August 2006) was an [[Austria]]n communications technician of [[Czech people|Czech]] origin. Přiklopil was born to Karl and Waltraud Přiklopil, in [[Vienna]], and was an only child. His father, Karl, was a cognac salesman and his mother, Waltraud, a shoe saleswoman.<ref name="GUARD1206">{{cite news|title=The silence of the lamb|work=The Guardian|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2099-2483706_2,00.html|accessdate=10 December 2006| location=London|author=Patrick Foster}}</ref> Přiklopil worked for a time at [[Siemens AG|Siemens]] as a communications technician.
Evidence recovery was complicated by the fact that Přiklopil's only computer was a 1980s Commodore 64, which is incompatible with modern-day data recovery programs.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/austria/article/0,,1865500,00.html|title=Kidnapper's retro computer offers scant clues|author=Mark Oliver|date=5 September 2006|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref>
He was buried under the name "Karl Wendelberger" on 8 September 2006 in the Piplitz family grave plot{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} in the town of [[Laxenburg]], south of Vienna.
Přiklopil allegedly had a daughter with the sister of a business partner.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2303168/Natascha-Kampuschs-father-names-second-kidnapper-claims-police-covered-errors-search-daughter-explosive-new-book.html|title=Natascha Kampusch's father names a second kidnapper and claims police covered up errors in the search for his daughter in explosive new book|author=Allan Hall|date=3 April 2013|work=Daily Mail|location=London}}</ref>
Before Kampusch escaped, Přiklopil was trying to procure false papers as a Czech citizen, in order to "begin a new life" with Kampusch.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/crooked-nose-drove-kampusch-kidnapper-claims-his-best-friend-2044822.html Crooked nose drove Kampusch kidnapper claims his best friend], The Independent</ref>
{{Clear}}
== After the escape == In her official statement Kampusch said "I don't want and will not answer any questions about personal or intimate details".<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/5293198.stm | title= Text: Austria kidnap girl's statement | work= | publisher= [[BBC News Online]] | pages= | page= | date= 28 August 2006 | accessdate= 30 August 2006 }}</ref> After Kampusch's escape, police investigated whether Přiklopil had an accomplice.<ref>* [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]], 25 August 2006. "[http://news.orf.at/060825-3165/index.html Hatte Entführer einen Komplizen?]". Accessed 25 August 2006 {{de icon}}</ref> Eventually, it was determined Přiklopil acted alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130415-kampusch-kidnapper-acted-alone-fbi-inquiry-priklopil-austria/|title=Europe – Kampusch kidnapper acted alone, probe finds – France 24|work=France 24}}</ref>
In the documentary, "Natascha Kampusch: 3096 days in captivity", Kampusch sympathised with her captor. She said "I feel more and more sorry for him—he's a poor soul", in spite of the fact that he held her captive for eight years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6958733.stm |title=Ex-kidnap girl attracts media glare |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=23 August 2007|accessdate=23 August 2007 | first=Tristana | last=Moore}}</ref> According to police she "cried inconsolably" when she was told he was dead,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14497151/ |title=Kidnapped girl weeps for dead 'master' – World news – Europe |publisher=MSNBC |date=26 August 2006 |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> and lit a candle for him at the morgue.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5327772.stm |title=Natascha abductor buried secretly |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=8 September 2006|accessdate=23 August 2007}}</ref> She has, however, referred to her captor as a "criminal".<ref>{{cite news|first= Kate|last=Connolly |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/09/07/wnatascha07.xml|title=Kidnapped Austrian Teenager Thought ‘Only of Escape' |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 September 2006|accessdate=7 September 2006 | location=London}}</ref>
Newspapers quoting unnamed psychologists suggested Kampusch may suffer from [[Stockholm syndrome]],<!-- a new so called Vienna syndrome, see also:http://www.zeit.de/2006/39/Titel-Richter-39?page=all --><ref>{{cite news|url=http://a.abcnews.com/GMA/story?id=2379231&page=1 |title=Escaped Austrian Teen May Have Stockholm Syndrome |publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=31 August 2006|accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5280472.stm |title=Austrian girl 'found' after years |publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=24 August 2006 |accessdate=15 October 2008}}</ref> but Kampusch, in her book ''3096 Tage'' (''3,096 Days'') says this is not the case. She suggests that people who use this term about her are disrespectful of her and do not allow her the right to describe and analyse the complex relationship she had with her kidnapper in her own words.
In 2009, Kampusch became the new face of [[animal rights]] group [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] in Austria. In June, Kampusch wrote to [[Ilse Aigner]], agriculture minister in Germany where the campaign is based, demanding freedom for zoo animals, stating: "The animals would, if they could, flee as I did, because a life in captivity is a life full of deprivation. It is up to you whether social, intelligent and wonderful creatures are to be freed from their chains and cages where ruthless people keep them."<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1194077/Cellar-victim-Natascha-Kampusch-strip-animal-rights.html Cellar victim Natascha Kampusch may strip for animal rights], [[Daily Mail]], 19 June 2009</ref>
In January 2009, Vienna's public prosecutor stated that DNA tests and questioning of witnesses had led to theories being discounted that Přiklopil had an accomplice. Kampusch has also maintained that her captor acted alone.<ref>BBC News, 8 January 2010.</ref>
=== Interviews === After reportedly "hundreds of requests for an interview" with the teenager, "with media outlets offering vast sums of money", Kampusch was interviewed by Austrian public broadcaster [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]]. The interview was broadcast on 6 September 2006 with her approval.<!-- Wednesday, 18:15 (UTC) and a copy by RTL Television: 19:15 (UTC) --> ORF did not pay for its interview,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5313762.stm|title=Kidnap girl to give TV interview |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=4 September 2006|accessdate=4 September 2006}}</ref> and said any proceeds from selling the interview to other channels would be forwarded to Kampusch. The interview was sold to more than 120 countries at a fee of 290 euros per minute. This money, estimated to some hundred thousand euros,<ref> http://www.extradienst.at/jaos/page/main_heute.tmpl?article_id=18721&offset=0</ref> was to be donated to women in Africa and Mexico by Kampusch. Likewise she was planning projects to help these women.<ref>''Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung'': Natascha Kampusch - the interview, 7 September 2006</ref> Interest was enormous.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/media/article1446532.ece|title=Natascha Kampusch: 400 interview requests — that was just the start|work=The Independent|date=11 September 2006|accessdate=11 September 2006|location=London|first=Alexandra|last=Buxton|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008134748/http://news.independent.co.uk/media/article1446532.ece|archivedate=8 October 2006}}</ref>
The newspaper ''[[Kronen Zeitung]]'' and news magazine ''[[NEWS (Austrian magazine)|NEWS]]'' also interviewed Kampusch. The interview was published on 6 September 2006. Both press interviews were given in return for a package including housing support, a long-term job offer, and help with her education.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://derstandard.at/?url=/?id=2574050|title=Kampusch spricht – am Boulevard|publisher=[[Der Standard|derStandard.at]] |date=6 September 2006|accessdate=8 September 2006|language=de}}</ref>
New developments<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.orf.at/video/iptvpopup.html?natascha_kampusch_interview_final_o.wmv|title=Part of an Interview with Natascha: The Kampusch Case — A Chronicle of Failure|publisher=[[ORF 2]]|date=11 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080214113326/http://news.orf.at/video/iptvpopup.html?natascha_kampusch_interview_final_o.wmv <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 14 February 2008|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://wien.orf.at/stories/255889|title= ORF-Interview|publisher=ORF|date=11 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008|language=de}}</ref> challenged the Austrian government in February 2008. Politicians of the conservative [[Austrian People's Party]] (ÖVP) threatened to break up the newly formed [[SPÖ]]–[[ÖVP]] ("red–black") coalition government in April and May 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stern.de/politik/panorama/:Ermittlungspannen-Fall-Kampusch-Regierungskrise/610685.html |title=Ermittlungspannen – Fall Kampusch führt zur Regierungskrise|publisher=[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]|date=12 February 2008|accessdate=12 February 2008|language=de}}</ref> Kampusch said that she had lost confidence in Austrian justice. Revelations of mistakes in the interior ministry's investigation of her kidnapping came to light, as well as statements of a policeman which were repeatedly ignored in 1998.{{Citation needed|date=September 2014}}
On 16 June 2008, the newspaper ''[[The Times]]'' published an in-depth interview with Kampusch by Bojan Pancevski and [[Stefanie Marsh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/article4044283.ece?print=yes |title=Natascha Kampusch: from darkness to limelight |accessdate=16 June 2008 |last=Pancevski |first=Bojan |author2=Marsh, Stefanie |date=2 June 2008 |publisher=[[The Times|Times Online]] |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615175158/http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/article4044283.ece?print=yes |archivedate=15 June 2011 }}</ref>
On 17 February 2010, the British TV channel [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]] broadcast an hour-long documentary about the case, including an exclusive interview with Kampusch: ''Natascha: the Girl in the Cellar''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Simon|first1=Jane|title=Natascha: The girl in the Cellar, FIVE, 8pm|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/natascha-the-girl-in-the-cellar-five-8pm-201922|accessdate=13 March 2017|work=the Daily Mirror|publisher=MGN Limited|date=17 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Natascha: The Girl In The Cellar|url=http://www.documentarytube.com/videos/natascha-the-girl-in-the-cellar|website=DocumentaryTube|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref>
=== Books === The book ''Girl in the Cellar: the Natascha Kampusch Story''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Girl-Cellar-Natascha-Kampusch-Story/dp/0340936487 |title=Girl in the Cellar |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> by Allan Hall and Michael Leidig appeared in November 2006, written in English. Kampusch's lawyer described the book as being both speculative and premature, and therefore planned to take legal action against it.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,451732,00.html Skandal-Buch über entführte Natascha erzürnt Familie] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711143400/http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,451732,00.html |date=11 July 2007 }}, ''Der Spiegel,'' 30. November 2006. {{de icon}}</ref>
Together with two journalists, Kampusch's mother Brigitta Sirny wrote a book about the ordeal, ''Verzweifelte Jahre'' ("Desperate Years"). Kampusch appeared at the initial presentation of the book in August 2007, but did not want to be photographed or interviewed. Sirny writes that she did not have much contact with Kampusch after the escape because Kampusch was shielded from the outside world.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,499269,00.html "Natürlich verdiene ich daran"] ''Spiegel Online,'' 10 August 2007. {{de icon}}</ref>
Kampusch wrote a book about her ordeal, ''3096 Tage'' (''3,096 Days''), published in September 2010.<ref>[http://www.focus.de/panorama/welt/entfuehrungsfall-kampusch-schreibt-autobiografie_aid_522314.html Entführungsfall: Kampusch schreibt Autobiografie] {{de icon}}</ref> It was adapted into a German movie, ''[[3096]]'', in 2013.
On 12 August 2016 Natascha Kampusch released her second book titled ''10 Years of Freedom''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kampusch|first1=Natascha|title=10 Jahre Freiheit" {{!}} Natascha Kampusch|url=http://natascha-kampusch.at/das-neue-buch-von-natascha-kampusch-10-jahre-freiheit/|website=natascha-kampusch.at|accessdate=13 March 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="Saying No to defeat is the only way to survive" – Interview with Natascha Kampusch|url=http://www.moonproject.co.uk/saying-no-to-defeat-is-the-only-way-to-survive-interview-with-natascha-kampusch/|website=MoonProject|accessdate=13 March 2017|date=21 February 2017}}</ref>
=== Media endeavors === Kampusch established her own website containing personal information including pictures of herself on 5 December 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://natascha-kampusch.at/|title=Natascha Kampusch|publisher=}}</ref> She had her own talk show on the new Austria TV channel, PULS 4,<!--http://www.puls4.com--> starting on 1 June 2008<!--http://www.kurier.at/kultur/163008.php-->. The show had the working title of ''In Conversation with…Natascha Kampusch'' and eventually premiered as ''Natascha Kampusch trifft'' (''Natascha Kampusch meets...'').<ref name="tvshow">[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/programming/a81588/kidnapped-austrian-girl-to-host-own-show.html Kidnapped Austrian girl to host own show] Digital Spy, 13 December 2007</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/kultur/medien/380538/index.do |title=DiePresse.com |publisher=DiePresse.com |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> It ran for only three shows.
On 17 June 2010, German film-maker and director [[Bernd Eichinger]] announced that he was making a film based on Kampusch's captivity and wanted [[Kate Winslet]] to star in the film.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/jun/17/kate-winslet-natascha-kampusch | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Natascha Kampusch film director eyes Kate Winslet as lead | first=Xan | last=Brooks | date=17 June 2010}}</ref> Bernd Eichinger died on 24 January 2011; Kampusch attended his funeral.<ref>{{cite news|title=German filmmaker Bernd Eichinger dies at 61|work=Reuters|date=25 January 2011|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/25/us-eichinger-idUSTRE70O7W420110125|accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref>
In 2011, the Austrian film ''[[Michael (2011 Austrian film)|Michael]]'', which has a plot that resembles the Natascha Kampusch case, was released.
On 15 April 2012, a German newspaper reported that a movie based on her autobiography with the same name was to be made, featuring [[Antonia Campbell-Hughes]] as Kampusch<ref>{{cite news|title=Film review: Natascha Kampusch’s eight years in captivity – distilled into 111 minutes of cinematic brutality in 3096 Days|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=March 2015|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/film-review-natascha-kampuschs-eight-years-in-captivity--distilled-into-111-minutes-of-cinematic-brutality-in-3096-days-8517557.html}}</ref> and [[Thure Lindhardt]] as Přiklopil. The movie ''3096 Tage'' (3096 days<!--http://www.3096tage.de -->) was directed by [[Sherry Hormann]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Flower|first=Alex|title=N.Irish actress to play Natascha Kampusch in movie: report|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Natascha+Kampusch/articles/NV7dX5IdzuH/N+Irish+actress+play+Natascha+Kampusch+movie|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130210024628/http://www.zimbio.com/Natascha+Kampusch/articles/NV7dX5IdzuH/N+Irish+actress+play+Natascha+Kampusch+movie|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 February 2013|accessdate=16 December 2012|newspaper=[[Zimbio]]|date=15 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Story of kidnap victim Natascha Kampusch set to be turned into film – with unknown Irish actress in lead role|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2130980/Story-kidnap-victim-Natascha-Kampusch-set-turned-film-called-3-096--Northern-Irish-actress-Antonia-Campbell-Hughes-lead-role.html|accessdate=16 December 2012|newspaper=Mail Online|date=17 April 2012|location=London}}</ref> and was released on 28 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Natascha Kampusch im Interview mit BILD – Zum 1. Mal spricht sie über ihre Vergewaltigung|url=http://www.bild.de/unterhaltung/leute/natascha-kampusch/im-interview-mit-bild-28580692.bild.html|accessdate=19 February 2013|newspaper=Bild.de|date=19 February 2013}}</ref>
=== House === [[File:Das Haus von Wolfgang Priklopil.jpg|thumb|Wolfgang Přiklopil's house in [[Strasshof]]]] The house where Kampusch was imprisoned was built by Přiklopil's grandfather, Oskar Přiklopil, after [[World War II]].<ref name="GUARD1206"/> During the [[Cold War]] period, Oskar and his son Karl built a [[Air-raid shelter|bomb shelter]], thought to be the origin of Kampusch's dungeon. Přiklopil took over the house in 1984 following his grandmother's death.
Kampusch now owns the house in which she was imprisoned, saying, "I know it's grotesque – I must now pay for electricity, water and taxes on a house I never wanted to live in". It was reported that she claimed the house from Přiklopil's estate because she wanted to protect it from vandals and being torn down; she also noted that she has visited it since her escape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30200-1316125,00.html|title=Kidnap Victim Owns Her House of Horrors|publisher=Sky News|date=15 May 2008|accessdate=15 May 2008}}</ref> When the third anniversary of her escape approached, it was revealed she had become a regular visitor at the property and was cleaning it out possibly to move in herself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.austriantimes.at/news/Panorama/2009-07-30/15162/Kampusch_to_auction_off_horror_house_items |title=Kampusch to auction off horror house items – Panorama – Austrian Times |work= |accessdate=15 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688Ynv8tb?url=http://www.austriantimes.at/news/Panorama/2009-07-30/15162/Kampusch_to_auction_off_horror_house_items |archivedate=3 June 2012 }}</ref>
In January 2010, Kampusch said she had retained the house because it was such a big part of her formative years, also stating that she would fill in the cellar if it is ever sold, adamant that it will never become a macabre museum to her lost adolescence.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1245899/Natascha-Kampusch-If-I-sell-house-I-held-captive-half-years-I-make-sure-cellar-filled-in.html Natascha Kampusch: He put me inside the cellar for eight-and-a-half years, preserved alive like an Egyptian pharaoh], ''Daily Mail''. Retrieved 26 January 2010.</ref> The cellar was indeed filled in, though Kampusch still owns the house.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QAxRCnoa9Aw Abductee Natascha Kampusch speaks out about her 8 years in captivity], YouTube</ref>
==See also== * [[Fritzl case]] * [[Jaycee Dugard]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}} <!--please integrate into the body of the article, in ref format Thanks.--> <!-- (source: German television RTL: it is own hand-writing by himself, by secret photos of the so called letter by RTL,two days ago, see also: http://derstandard.at: "Zu dem vor einigen Tagen verlesenen Brief des Entführungsopfers bekräftigte Friedrich, dass es sich bei dem im Fernsehen gezeigten Schriftstück um eine Abschrift jener "Ideen und Gedanken" von Natascha Kampusch handelte – und nicht um das Original: "Das waren einzelne Zetteln, die ich in einem Tresor aufbewahre", so der Psychiater". --The so called letter is a fake, a so called "half fake", Kampusch Brief ist eine Zusammenfassung: "Das waren einzelne Zetteln, die ich in einem Tresor aufbewahre", so der Psychiater. Er habe den Text eins zu eins übertragen, lediglich die Reihenfolge der Textpassagen sei – in Absprache mit Kampusch – verändert worden. (APA)" -->
==Further reading== * Natascha Kampusch, ''3,096 Days'', (Penguin, 2010) {{ISBN|978-0-670-91999-4}}. * Allan Hall and Michael Leidig, ''The Girl in the Cellar'', (Hodder, 2009) {{ISBN|978-0-340-99787-1}}. * Natascha Kampusch, mit Corinna Milborn und Heike Gronemeier: ''3096 Tage''. List, Berlin 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-471-35040-9}}. * Pelu, Martin: ''Der Fall Natascha Kampusch''. Tectum, Marburg 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-8288-2294-8}}; 2013 auch als E-Book, {{ISBN|978-3-8288-5608-0}}. * [[Kathrin Röggla]]: ''Die Beteiligten'', Theaterstück, 2009<ref>Ulrike Gondorf: ''[http://www.dradio.de/dkultur/sendungen/fazit/951681/ Der Fall Kampusch auf der Bühne.]'' In: ''[[Deutschlandradio Kultur]]'' vom 19. April 2009.</ref> * Sirny-Kampusch, Brigitta: ''Verzweifelte Jahre, ein Leben ohne Natascha''. Aufgezeichnet von Andrea Fehringer und Thomas Köpf, Ueberreuter, Wien 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-8000-7295-8}}.
== External links == {{Wikinews|Austrian teenager mourns captor's suicide}} * [http://www.natascha-kampusch.at Natascha Kampusch's Official Homepage] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/28/world/europe/28iht-web.0828aletter.2617398.html English translation by [[International Herald Tribune]] of open letter released by Kampusch on 28 August 2006] * [http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung.php?schluessel=OTS_20060824_OTS0216 Diagram and pictures of the hidden room] by Federal Criminal Police Office of Austria
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kampusch, Natascha}} [[Category:1988 births]] [[Category:1990s missing person cases]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]] [[Category:Austrian autobiographers]] [[Category:Austrian television presenters]] [[Category:Formerly missing people]] [[Category:Kidnapped Austrian children]] [[Category:Kidnappings in Austria]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Austria]] [[Category:Rape in Austria]] [[Category:Writers from Vienna]]

The '''Nineteen Martyrs of Aklan''' ([[Filipino language|Filipino]]: ''Labinsiyam na mga Martir ng Aklan''; [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Diecinueve mártires de Aklan'') were Filipino patriots in [[Kalibo]], [[Aklan]], Philippines who were executed by musketry on March 23, 1897 at 2 am, for cooperating with the [[Katipunan]] during the [[Philippine Revolution]] against Spain.
==Martyrs == {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * Roman Aguirre * Tomas Briones * Valeriano Dalida * Domingo dela Cruz * Claro Delgado * [[Angelo Fernandez]] * Benito Iban * [[Candido Iban]] * Simeon Inocencio * Isidro Jimenez * Catalino Mangat * Lamberto Mangat * Valeriano Masinda * Maximo Mationg * Simplicio Reyes * Canuto Segovia * Gavino Sucgang * Francisco Villorente * Gavino Yunsal
}}
==History== [[General Francisco del Castillo]], a close associate of [[Andres Bonifacio]]. This Aklanon Katipunero was tasked by Bonifacio to establish [[Katipunan]] in [[Panay Island]]. On March 17, 1897, the young patriot, defender of liberty and leader of the Aklan revolutionists was killed by an assassin during a fight in the present-day Pastrana Park. The untimely death of Gen. del Castillo had signaled the end of the major struggle for freedom in Aklan. His close friends, assistants and soldiers were forced to give up arms, some due to the promise of receiving amnesty. These Nineteen Men, weak from hunger and thirst and racked with rain, were bound together and forced into a black hole of a stone cell on Amadeo Street (now Nineteen Martyrs Street) in [[Kalibo]]. Here their hands were manacled and a long bamboo pole was passed through their locked arms across their mangled backs. Then they were strung high up against the wall of the cell, with their backs to the firing line, and during the first hours of March 23, they were shot to death. The few who did not die instantly were bayoneted. That was a night of darkness and terror in [[Kalibo]]. But such promise was quickly broken. So on the fateful day of March 23, 1897, the Martyrs of Aklan were executed.
==Legacy== On March 23, 1897, all 19 prisoners were summarily executed by a firing squad in the town square. Their bodies were hastily buried in a mass grave inside a cemetery. By virtue of a Municipal Council resolution, the mortal remains of 19 martyrs were transferred to its present site at corner M. Laserna and Veterans’ Avenue on March 23, 1926. In order to commemorate the death anniversary of the 19 Martyrs of Aklan, Republic Act No. 7806 was made into law setting the 23rd day of March of every year as a special public holiday in the Province of Aklan. A former general himself, President [[Fidel V. Ramos]] let Republic Act 7806 lapsed into law without his signature. And on September 1, 1994, in accordance with Article VI, Sec. 27(1) of the Constitution became law.
On the 102th martyrdom anniversary of the 19 Martyrs of Aklan on March 23, 2018, the [[National Historical Commission of the Philippines]] officially turned over to the Provincial Government of Aklan a tableau memorial in honor of the freedom heroes at the Goding Ramos Park.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Thirteen Martyrs Of Cavite}} [[Category:Paramilitary Filipinos]] [[Category:People of the Philippine Revolution|19 Martyrs of Aklan]] [[Category:People of Spanish colonial Philippines]] [[Category:1897 deaths]] [[Category:Executed Filipino people]] [[Category:People executed by Spain by firearm]] [[Category:History of the Philippines (1521–1898)]] [[Category:History of Aklan]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people|Thirteen Martyrs of Cavite 0323]] <!-- Cavite earliest -->

revision.text:
[[Image:Hagardom.jpg|thumb|Monument commemorating the Olei Hagardom, [[Ramat Gan]]]]
'''Olei Hagardom''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: "Those hanged in the [[gallows]]", עולי הגרדום) refers to members of the two [[Jew]]ish [[Revisionist Zionism|Revisionist]] pre-state underground organisations [[Irgun]] and [[Lehi (group)|Lehi]], who were tried in [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|British Mandate]] courts and sentenced to death by [[hanging]], most of them in [[Acre Subdistrict, Mandatory Palestine|Acre]] prison. There were 12 ''Olei Hagardom''.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|last=Sheleg |first=Yair |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/846330.html |title=The good jailer - Haaretz - Israel News |publisher=Haaretz |date=2007-04-07 |accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
The term does not include members of the [[Nili]] organisation hanged by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] government during [[World War I]].
==History== The [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate for Palestine]] was an instrument of government instituted by the [[League of Nations]] for the administration of territories formerly under the rule of the [[Ottoman Empire]]. British rule lasted from 1917-1948.
During the [[1936–1939 Arab revolt in Palestine|1936–1939 Arab revolt]], the militant group known as the [[Irgun]] embarked on an intensive armed campaign against [[Arab]] targets. Later British targets were added also. With the outbreak of [[World War II]], militant actions against the British were halted, but one of the leaders of the group, [[Avraham Stern]], insisted that the fight must go on, leading to a split in the Irgun which led to the formation of a new group, [[Lehi (group)|Lehi]] (also known as the Stern Gang). In 1944, the Irgun, now headed by [[Menachem Begin]] rejoined the fight against the British. After the end of World War II, the larger [[Haganah]] joined the fight within a union called the [[Jewish Resistance Movement]], which lasted for just about ten months, from October 1945 until August 1946.<ref name='Jewish Agency'>Jewish Agency for Israel, [http://jafi.org/JewishAgency/English/About/History/#t6The History of the Jewish Agency for Israel] Retrieved on 27 April 2012</ref>
The term "Olei HaGardom" refers to the eight Irgun and two Lehi members who were executed during this period and a further member of each group who committed suicide prior to their intended executions. Two of the executions were carried out in Egypt in 1945. With the exception of Ben Yosef, all the executions and suicides within the British Mandate of Palestine occurred in 1947. They were tried under the [[Defence (Emergency) Regulations|Defence Emergency Regulations]], enacted in September 1945. These regulations suspended [[Habeas Corpus]] and established Military courts. They prescribed the death penalty for various offences, including carrying weapons or ammunition and membership in an organization whose members commit these offenses.<ref>Guy Carmi, [http://www.irmgard-coninx-stiftung.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/archive/Guy_Carmi_III.pdf On the Constitutionality of the Death Penalty in Israel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719045009/http://www.irmgard-coninx-stiftung.de/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/archive/Guy_Carmi_III.pdf |date=2011-07-19 }}</ref>
==List of Olei Hagardom== [[Image:Olei-hagardom.jpg|thumb|Monument to Irgun members in [[Safed]]]] ===Original list=== *[[Shlomo Ben-Yosef]]: An Irgun member who was the first Oleh Hagardom. He was arrested after an attack on a bus carrying Arab civilians in [[Safed]]. He was executed on June 29, 1938. *[[Eliyahu Hakim]], Lehi member assassinated [[Lord Moyne]] in [[Cairo]]. Executed in Cairo on March 22, 1945. *[[Eliyahu Bet-Zuri]], Lehi member who assisted in the assassination of Lord Moyne and killed Moyne's British Army chaffeur, executed in Cairo on March 22, 1945. *[[Dov Gruner]]: Irgun member captured during a raid on the [[Palestine Police Force|Palestine Police]] station in [[Ramat Gan]]. He was executed on April 16, 1947. *[[Mordechai Alkahi]]: Irgun member arrested en route to an attack on British officers on the [[Night of the Beatings]]. Executed on April 16, 1947. *[[Yehiel Dresner]], Irgun member arrested en route to an attack on British officers on the Night of the Beatings. Executed on April 16, 1947. *[[Eliezer Kashani]], Irgun member arrested en route to an attack on British officers on the "[[Night of the Beatings]]". Executed on April 16, 1947. *[[Meir Feinstein]]: Irgun member captured after bombing [[Jerusalem]] train station. Committed suicide on April 21, 1947 while awaiting execution. *[[Moshe Barazani]]: Lehi member caught carrying a grenade, committed suicide on April 21, 1947 while awaiting execution. *[[Avshalom Haviv]]: Irgun member captured during the [[Acre Prison break]], executed on July 29, 1947. *[[Meir Nakar]], Irgun member captured during the Acre Prison break, executed on July 29, 1947. *[[Yaakov Weiss]], Irgun member captured during the Acre Prison break, executed on July 29, 1947.
===Expanded list=== The original list of Olei Hagardom was later extended after former Irgun commander [[Menachem Begin]] became Prime Minister of Israel.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/the-good-jailer-1.217549</ref> *Naaman Belkind, [[Nili]] member who spied for British military intelligence during [[World War I]], executed by the Ottoman authorities in [[Damascus]] on December 16, 1917. *[[Yosef Lishansky]], Nili member who spied for British military intelligence during World War I. Executed by the Ottoman authorities in Damascus on December 16, 1917. *[[Mordechai Schwarcz]], Jewish police officer who shot dead an Arab comrade, who he claimed had boasted about murdering Jews, executed on August 16, 1938. *[[Eli Cohen]], Israeli spy captured in [[Syria]] after having infiltrated the Syrian government, executed on May 18, 1965.
==Barazani and Feinstein== [[Moshe Barazani]] and [[Meir Feinstein]] committed suicide in their prison cell with [[grenade|handgrenades]] smuggled to them in a basket of oranges. The grenades were placed inside hollowed out orange peels.<ref>[https://www.haaretz.co.il/hasen/pages/ShArtStEngPE.jhtml?itemNo=846330&contrassID=2&subContrassID=14&title='The%20good%20jailer%20'&dyn_server=172.20.5.5 The good jailer - Haaretz - Israel News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The original plan was to carry the concealed grenades with them as they were taken to the gallows then use them to carry out a [[suicide attack]], but allegedly after they learned that Rabbi Goldman would be present at the time of the execution, the plan was dropped. Instead, Barazani and Feinstein blew themselves up in their jail cell shortly before the execution.
== Irgun and Lehi actions to stop the executions == {{Main|The Sergeants affair}} The Irgun adopted a policy of hostage-taking in response to British death sentences passed down on its members. After two Irgun fighters, Yosef Simchon and Michael Ashbel, were sentenced to death for raid on the Sarafand army base in 1946, the Irgun seized five British officers as hostages and threatened to hang them if the sentences were carried out. The sentences were commuted. After Dov Gruner and three other Irgun fighters captured during the Night of the Beatings were sentenced to death, the Irgun abducted a British judge and intelligence officer and threatened to kill its hostages if the sentences were carried out. The British announced an indefinite postponement in the executions, and the hostages were released, although the British later hanged the prisoners.<ref>Tzila Amidror Heller, ''Behind Prison Walls: A Jewish Woman Freedom Fighter for Israel's Independence''</ref> In addition, Lehi also managed to get the death sentences of 18 of its members commuted at one point after threatening to kill 100 Britons in response.
After Avshalom Haviv, Meir Nakar, and Yaakov Weiss were sentenced to death for their role in the [[Acre Prison break]], the Irgun kidnapped two British Army Intelligence Corps sergeants, [[The Sergeants affair|Clifford Martin and Mervyn Paice]] in [[Netanya]]. The Irgun announced that hanging its fighters would result in the subsequent hanging of the British soldiers. Haviv, Nakar, and Weiss were executed on July 29, 1947. The bodies of Clifford Martin and Mervyn Paice were subsequently found hanging from trees in a forest near Netanya. Their bodies had been booby-trapped with a [[Improvised Explosive Device|homemade bomb]].
[[Menachem Begin]] spoke of the event saying: "it was one of the most bitter moments of my life but the cruel action in Netanya not only saved dozens of Jews from the gallows but also broke the neck of the British occupation, because when the gallows break down, the British rule, which relied on it, breaks on its own".{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} After this event, there were no more executions of Jewish militants by the British.
==Commemoration == Many streets in Israel are named after Olei Hagardom, and postage stamps bearing their images have been issued. The [[Ramat HaHayal]] neighbourhood in Tel Aviv and the [[Armon HaNatziv]] neighbourhood in Jerusalem have streets bearing the name ''Olei Hagardom'' or the names of individual fighters.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In [[Ramat Gan]], there is an official square and statue honouring Dov Gruner and the Olei Hagardom. An official commemoration ceremony takes place on [[Yom Hazikaron]] at the memorial in [[Rishon LeZion]], which stands near Olei HaGardom Street, and the [[Knesset]] holds an annual memorial service for them.
==See also== * [[List of notable Irgun members]]
== References == {{Commonscat|Olei HaGardom}} <references/>
[[Category:Olei Hagardom| ]] [[Category:Hebrew words and phrases]] [[Category:Irgun]] [[Category:People executed by Mandatory Palestine by hanging]] [[Category:Terrorism in Mandatory Palestine]] [[Category:Articles about multiple people]]
